Not only is the government forgoing a long-term revenue stream for the benefit of the Australian community, but it is committing public money that could be spent for better purposes than to pay senior executives of stockbroking firms, merchant bankers, lawyers and financial advisers for massive sales costs. Two hundred million dollars has already been paid in fees and commissions for the initial public offer.

The full privatisation of Telstra is likely to cost the Australian taxpayer up to $800 million in sales fees. When people look at the cuts to public expenditure that the first Howard government has implemented—cuts to child care, to aged care, to public hospitals and employment services—many people will say, `Let's keep these public assets in government hands and direct this sale expenditure to much-needed community services.' While debate continues about the long-term budgetary losses from a privatised Telstra, there is little doubt that investors have made enormous profits. The one-third stake that the government sold for $14.3 billion is now worth $30 billion.

These are the cold, hard economic facts about the sale of Telstra. But what about the human effects and the issue of community service responsibilities. Telstra has been in a constant state of lowering its staff numbers. The effect has been a savage cut in services to all consumers, particularly those in rural Australia. These cuts are likely to continue. The Telstra chief executive has advised the government that the cost of subsidising rural telephone subscriptions was $1.8 billion a year. In the Financial Review of 21 October, in an article by Ivor Ries, the comment was made:
The $1.8 billion claim was a staggering $1.55 billion more than the government previously estimated of the cost of subsidising rural telephone users.

Having just been returned to office on a platform of providing world class telephone services to every town, Hamlet and farm in the back blocks of Australia, this Telstra claim rocked the foundation underlying the government's promise.
The Telstra chief executive has raised the incompatibility of shareholders' interests with Telstra's social service obligations.

In a speech to the National Press Club, Mr Blount referred to Telstra's growth potential being impeded if it continued to have to provide cross-subsidies such as single price for all local calls, no matter where they were made in Australia, rental subsidies for some phones, Telstra funding of the 000 emergency service and free directory assistance.

Under shareholder pressure, and facing the full privatisation of Telstra, are we once more looking at the appalling non-core promise behaviour from the government, with a further deterioration of telecommunications in the bush? The privatisation debate needs to be viewed from a social viewpoint as well as from the economic side of the argument. I strongly urge that based on current trends the evidence suggests that it would be more socially and economically responsible to retain what is left of our government infrastructure than it would be to place these assets on the open market.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, may I congratulate you on your election to the Speaker's Panel and wish you well in that position.

speech.para: This afternoon I want to speak about the dangers of mobile phones. I am not talking about the health risks of mobile phones; I am talking about the financial dangers of mobile phones. Most people would not realise that as part of the service when they hook up to a mobile phone they have access to 0055, 1900 and overseas international calls. This is a problem that affects a lot of people in Australia because Australians love mobile phones.

Having had a look at the research that was done by the Parliamentary Library on the growth of mobile phone use in Australia, it was quite extraordinary to see how significantly the Australian mobile phone market has grown over the last two years. There were one million subscribers in March 1994, two million in June 1995 and in October 1997 over five million Australians had a mobile phone. The size of the Australian mobile phone market is estimated to grow to some 6.5 million subscribers by the year 2000, which represents an annual average growth of 13.7 per cent.

In 1995, Australia had the fourth highest rate of cellular mobile phone penetration amongst OECD countries. Only Sweden, Norway and Finland showed higher rates of mobile phone ownership. It seems almost everyone in Australia has a mobile phone. As a parent of two young men—teenagers—I have been very pleased that they have had access to mobile phones in the last couple of years. It is also comforting to know that my wife has a mobile phone with her when she is driving late at night. I know that is now the situation in most Australian families. So what I am talking about today does not just affect one or two people, it affects virtually every Australian family.

I have chosen to highlight the issue today because a number of very distressing cases have come to my attention. The first one of those received a great deal of publicity in some of the national media. I was contacted by a constituent of mine, Mr Brian Smith, who had a mobile phone which he did not use very much. He was a small businessman and he had the phone in his van. He did not realise for a couple of days that it had been stolen. He went looking for it and found that it had disappeared. When he contacted Telstra—his provider at the time—to get his mail off the voice mail, he discovered that he had a phone bill of $18,495 for which, according to the carrier, he was responsible.

Through negotiations we managed to help Mr Smith. The people who had stolen his phone were identified and charged, which meant that responsibility for the cost of those calls could then be transferred to those people who had been charged with stealing his phone. Since that time, I have been contacted by another two constituents from Umina Beach who are in exactly the same situation and now face a phone bill of $6,799.50. They were not aware that their mobile phone had been stolen. I believe it was less than two days before they notified the phone company that it was missing. I have not been successful in convincing the carrier to waive this phone bill.

There are many other people who are in the same situation. Most people do not read the fine print when they sign a mobile phone contract, but they are responsible for that mobile phone, responsible for the calls that are made from that mobile phone and have a responsibility to notify the carrier the minute they no longer have control of that phone. Most of us occasionally—quite often frequently—put down our mobile phone and cannot find it again, and it may be 24 hours before we discover where it is. It is quite frightening to think that if someone had picked up that phone and decided to dial 1900 numbers—which are rated at something like $5 per minute—and either left that phone on or used it for an extensive period of time, the owner of that phone could be responsible for a bill of something like $5,000 or $6,000 in a matter of one day.

When I was investigating this case on behalf of my constituents at Umina, I spoke to the detectives at Gosford police station. They informed me that they are currently investigating 14 cases of stolen mobile phones—in excess of $2,000 each—all in the Woy Woy peninsula area and involving 1900 and 0055 numbers. So it is not an isolated case.

I guess technology has moved faster than the legislators and the insurance companies. We need to do something about it because the lives of these people are being ruined. Small business people and families are being hit with these huge bills. It is not possible to insure against these bills. If someone breaks into your home and steals goods worth $18,000, you can insure against that. Hopefully your insurance company will cover you for it and you will get new goods and get on with your life. But if someone breaks into your home and steals your mobile phone and then racks up $18,000 worth of mobile phone calls, you cannot insure against that. You are responsible for that unless those culprits are caught. It is something that has to be changed.

I have written to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston, and he is investigating my concerns. I put to him that surely we could put in place a discussion paper, a code of practice or, if necessary, legislation which would limit the liability of mobile phone owners to perhaps a few hundred dollars. At the moment, liability is totally unlimited. Most people realise that if they have their wallet stolen and their credit card is used, there is a limit to the amount that can be charged on their credit card so that there is not financial ruin.

The mobile phone industry has moved quicker than governments and legislators. At the moment, every one of us who has a mobile phone which has access to 1900 or 0055 numbers is risking financial ruin if we misplace our phone and then it is stolen and used to dial those 1900 numbers. In my own area—the peninsula area—it is known, particularly to the younger teenage people in the area, that if they steal a mobile phone they can use it to access these 1900 information lines, which are often sex lines from overseas and are charged, as I said, at about $5 per minute. It seems to be a bit of a game to them and they do not realise that innocent families are then being hit with these huge bills.

I urge every single one of the 6½ million people in Australia who own mobile phones, who do not need access to overseas or information calls, to ring their provider and ask for those calls to be barred. It is a simple phone call. I have done it with my family's mobile phones and I encourage everyone else to do the same—to ring up and ask for those numbers to be barred. If you do need to make an overseas call, you can ring your provider, give identification and have the service put back on. I am telling everyone in Australia to get on to their providers.

More than that, I encourage the providers to look at the fact that, at the moment, these services are provided without request. When you get a mobile phone, these services are included as part of that connection. Surely it would be safer for the consumer if those services were not included unless they were requested by the consumer. Most of us tend not to use our mobile phones for overseas or information calls and it would be much safer if they were not in the initial contract. I appeal to the providers—and there are a number of them now throughout the Australian community—to look at the possibility of having that service put on the mobile phone on request and not automatically.

talk.start.para: —I rise in the parliament today to bring to the attention of the House a matter that has been raised with me by one of my constituents, Mr Rodney Miller of Moolap in the Corio electorate. Rod Miller called me, as his federal member, some time ago. He is an owner-driver of a semitrailer and he asked whether he could make an appointment to raise a matter of serious concern with me. I took the opportunity to visit him at his house on a Saturday, as I recall.

speech.para: I found Rodney Miller to be a proud man with a young family. He was proud of his house and proud of his semitrailer. He had worked hard and long for the economic benefits and position that he currently enjoyed. Trucking was a life that he obviously loved, one that enabled him to realise his dream of owning his home and owning his own truck. It was obvious that trucking was a life that offered him a chance of long-term employment, but he was not a well man when I visited him on that day. He was tired, he was pale and drawn and the story that he told me filled me with great concern. It is a story not only of Rodney Miller but of many truck drivers in this country today. It was a personal story which did not just relate to the personal health of drivers; it raised serious public safety issues as well.

Rod Miller was in both physical and emotional pain and he admitted to me that he and his truck were a threat to public safety on our highways. He stated that the heavy truck that he had purchased and which he used to make his living was riddled with structural defects. Not only were its structural deficiencies injurious to his health, but he had the potential to cause fatal accidents on our highways. He complained of acute tiredness at the wheel, exhaustion on the shorter haul runs, acute pain in his kidneys, urinating blood and chronic back problems that translated into numbness in his legs, all through driving his recently purchased truck. I am no expert in this field, but apparently mechanical vibration is acknowledged to be a serious occupational hazard, especially in surface transport. It induces drowsiness and a decrease in performance levels, as well as the matters that I have just raised.

Rodney Miller is a responsible citizen. He took his truck off the road at considerable personal cost, simply because he could not operate the truck within the law as it was and he feared not only for his own safety but for the safety of others on the road. He brought an action against the manufacturer of the truck, and I understand that that matter is before the courts as I speak today. I do not propose to make any further comment on that case because I think it is appropriate that we let the legal processes run their course.

In the process of gathering evidence of the situation that he found himself in, Rodney Miller came across truckies from all over Australia who were suffering similar problems to himself. He sought expert engineering evidence to substantiate the claims that he was making against the truck manufacturer. Those of course would have to be tested, but a cursory reading of that evidence would suggest that something is seriously wrong with some of the heavy vehicles that are on our roads today. He received an engineering report from McLeod Engineering Services Pty Ltd, computer aided engineering, that had this to say:
In conclusion it is clear that the—
I will omit the type of truck and just use the word `truck'—
. . . and in particular Rod Miller's unit suffers from several serious design deficiencies which make the vehicle entirely unsuited for the purpose for which it was purchased.

The serious vibration environment makes it impossible for the driver to sit in it for the periods of time that a truck of this type would be driven for at a stretch without suffering injury caused by vibrations. The vibrations create a requirement for substantial additional maintenance above and beyond what was envisaged when the vehicle was purchased.
The report goes on to say:

The deficiencies in the suspension and chassis stiffness create serious handling problems as well as seriously reducing the life of the tyres below the tyre life that competitive vehicles show. To summarise the truck is too hard to sit in and drive, to control when it is being driven and it costs far more to own and to maintain than similar vehicles that don't have these problems.

That was not the only report that Mr Miller commissioned. Another report which related to a different type of rig from the same manufacturer was prepared by A. Enkelman and Associates Pty Ltd. And once again it dealt with the structural deficiencies in heavy vehicles. That company had this to say:

It is the considered opinion of the undersigned that this vehicle is of unmerchantable quality in its present condition as it displays dynamic characteristics which degrades primary safety to unacceptable levels, endangering not only the occupants of this vehicle but other road users.

But by far the most damning report on prime mover design deficiencies came from Dr Arnold McLean from the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Wollongong. In correspondence to the department of transport, he listed a whole series of very technical and detailed deficiencies. I will not read them all to the House. Perhaps I will put them on the public record at some other time. He had this to say:
. . . there is no other recourse than to recommend the subject vehicles be declared as
UNSAFE, UNROADWORTHY AND BE IMMEDIATELY WITHDRAWN FROM SERVICE.
Furthermore, due to imminent failure, consistent with points (i) to (iii) above, all paramount vehicle components are not suitable for spare parts or reuse.
I will read points (i) to (iii) into Hansard . They are:
(i) the manufacturer's inherent design fault,
(ii) generally irreversible strain energy accumulation in paramount prime mover components during operation,
(iii) irreversible metal fatigue of paramount prime mover components during operation exacerbated by dynamic loading far in excess of the nominal static loads . . .

There is also other material, which I do not have time to present to the House tonight in this grievance debate. As I stand here tonight, Rodney Miller's house is on the market. The bank is moving in on the loan that he secured to buy the truck of his dreams. The family is under serious financial and emotional strain. All of us in this place have interviewed constituents who, due to their emotional state, have walked very fine lines as far as their personal health is concerned. I spoke to the Miller family recently, and I was saddened by the emotional state that I found this family in.

This matter has been reported to the Federal Office of Road Safety. Tonight I say this to the Federal Office of Road Safety: I hope that all that can be done has been done to investigate this matter. In my heart of hearts—on what I have been told and how I have been informed—I do not `think all is well in the state of Denmark' as far as this issue is concerned. It is not an issue that relates to one man but to many families across the length and breadth of Australia. The member for Kennedy will attest to that as well. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Given the amount of mail that arrives in my electorate office each day, there are relatively few letters addressing the vital issue of drugs. Perhaps this is because the community at large is, quite understandably, unsure about how we can adequately deal with the scourge of drugs. However, it is an issue that is always with us, affecting many thousands of us directly and all of us in some way or another. The few letters that do come from my constituents about drugs rarely contain advice. They are usually desperate cries for help, emanating from family, from friends and from addicts themselves.

speech.para: So how do we respond, especially when views in the community range from zero tolerance through to full legalisation? While legalising drug use would be largely unacceptable to the community, treating drug users as criminals seemingly has done little to ease the problem. In Victoria, the Kennett government has trialled the Cannabis Cautioning Program with some success. Now it is being introduced state wide and will involve police issuing cautions to low level users who have no previous history of drug use. It is an attempt to educate drug users, rather than prosecute them, to sharpen the focus on harm minimisation.

By way of contrast, I note that experts are attributing the sixth successive drop in US annual crime figures to the Zero Tolerance Program, pioneered by Mayor Rudolf Giuliani of New York City, and its adoption by other major cities. Mayor Giuliani wants to arrest all users of marijuana. This approach is at the other end of the spectrum. Both approaches indicate to me that at the very least among governments and community groups there is an acceptance of a real problem which cannot be allowed to defeat us. Federal, state and local governments, churches and many community organisations are all involved, committing ever-increasing funds and resources in an attempt to, as Professor Penington termed it, `turn the tide'.

Drug usage no longer occurs only in certain areas. We no longer believe that paying for a private school education will shield our young from temptation. We no longer presume that users of drugs are all society drop-outs or bad kids. Drugs are in every suburb, not just in the inner city, and have permeated every socioeconomic strata. In Melbourne's east, we have seen police blitzes drive out some of the visible drug use in Box Hill, but in reality all they have done is move it to nearby Mitcham. When the police have moved their concentration to Mitcham, the activity has moved along again—a situation which is repeated from suburb to suburb, from one side of Australia to the other.

Deakin's leafier suburbs of Ringwood North and Blackburn are similarly not immune. On many occasions I have pulled up the garage door to find syringes littering the laneway at the back of my house. It is of growing con cern to me as I look at my own six- and seven-year-old children and my ability to protect them from the parasitic overtures of schoolyard drug dealers.

While drug use is certainly not confined to our young people, it is they who are most vulnerable to the evil schemes of pushers of narcotics. Despite the intense education effort, there are still many who slip through the net and begin to take drugs. The national study on illicit drugs released last week indicated that 13 per cent of our 12-year-olds had used illegal substances. Further, 40 per cent of those aged between 12 and 17 had tried illegal drugs and 55 per cent of all 17-year-olds had used cannabis. These figures would indicate that most Australians who use drugs have had exposure to the scene at a very young age.

From discussions with drug users and youth workers, I know there are many reasons why the young use drugs. Whatever the reason, the initial try is usually a result of peer pressure or curiosity. We know that a young person's curiosity is not an easy thing to put a lid on. If drugs are available, there is a certain inevitability that some will not be able to avoid the temptation to try them.

Why many continue to use drugs, and progress to harder substances, is a more perplexing question. Feelings of hopelessness and despair, fuelled by a lack of parental support, employment opportunities and growing rates of homelessness are but some of the causes often given. Some of these young people consider themselves to be condemned to a life of misery for themselves and their families, turning to crime to finance their habit.

I look forward to the release of the Commonwealth's school drug education strategy soon. The Commonwealth is committing $17.5 million for education purposes as part of its larger $215 million Tough on Drugs program. From the two drug forums I have hosted in Deakin over the past two years, I know that we have some of the finest individuals and organisations working on the problem, with little reward except the considerable satisfaction of knowing that their work will save lives. In Melbourne's east there are over a dozen organisations operating under the banner of the Eastern Alcohol and Drug Association. These organisations offer assessments, referrals, consultation, counselling, community education, withdrawal programs, needle and syringe exchanges, support, therapy and other services for drug users and affected families. These people are perhaps in the best position to judge the types of services we need to offer to stamp out drugs.

Reach Out for Kids, better known as ROKs, is one organisation working in partnership with the community to better educate our young people and their parents about drugs and how to deal with them. Based in Nunawading, Reach Out for Kids, under the excellent leadership of their president, Terry McDonald, and the agency coordinator, David Monro, invited me recently to join the committee of management. I am honoured to receive such an invitation and look forward to contributing to their great work.

Over 20 years, Reach Out for Kids has aimed to provide a range of integrated services to assist economically, socially and emotionally disadvantaged children, youth and families. They have been extremely supportive of my initiative to bring schools, youth workers, medical practitioners and social welfare organisations together for a regional analysis on drug related issues, with a view to taking part in the Commonwealth's response.

At my most recent drug forum on 20 August, I spoke with and received great feedback from many local people working with drug issues. There was agreement on several points: that drug education is vital and best if it begins when children are young; that this education is not the sole responsibility of teachers and, in many ways, parents can better identify problems; that parents require education and training in this respect.

Linda Harrington from the Whitehorse Division of General Practice noted that general practitioners were often referring parents to her. She further endorsed the call for education and training and the need to offer a package to parents and general practitioners in order to combat the problem and provide those parents with the necessary skills. We know that poor parenting skills are frequently associated with young people's use of drugs. Parenting courses are a vital part of a response.

We also agreed that outside organisations, such as Reach Out for Kids, are a great help to schools because of their professional knowledge. Finally we agreed that the strengthening of the family relationship—an aspect that is often spoken about in this House—is of key importance in winning the battle.

Due to these two forums I have held, it is my wish to continue the dialogue with these very worthy organisations and people to establish an advisory committee made up of parents, teachers, young people and youth workers—a committee to keep me abreast of developments and to ensure that the government response meets our local needs. From a personal point of view, I hope to see our education process take root so that fewer young people take that first step into the drug culture.

One of the most common criticisms is the length of time that many people have to wait for rehabilitation and detoxification services. Due to a lack of sufficient resources, it seems that community workers are rarely available after hours, that answering machines predominate after dark. This is not to criticise youth and social workers but rather to highlight funding needs. A cry for help from an addict or family must be heard and acted upon immediately. The time between an appeal for help and the arrival of that helping hand is the best ally of those grim reapers known as pushers. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Fishing Vessels: Police and Customs Raid

talk.start.para: —This evening I would like to bring to the attention of the House a very disturbing event which took place just offshore Wollongong, in my electorate, in October. I refer to a raid conducted by 63 personnel of the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Customs Service on the fishing fleets that operate out of Wollongong harbour. The background to this, as I understand it, is as follows: a number of operators of fishing vessels that operate out of Wollongong have for some time now been involved in dispute with AFMA, the Australian Fishing Management Authority, in respect of the amount of fish that they are legally able to trawl for in the waters off Wollongong and further out to sea.

speech.para: Some years ago quotas were set. There has always been an ongoing discussion, whether it be about orange roughy or whatever, as to the scientific basis on which the quotas are set. The fishermen in question have always been prepared to sit down and actively engage in dialogue with representatives of AFMA and people from the then Department of Primary Industries and Energy, now the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Therefore, they found the manner in which this raid took place, and the fact that it took place in October, particularly galling.

Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, I am sure you can imagine the anguish that your family would feel if they suddenly found a 63-strong force of people from the AFP and the Australian Customs Service not only descending on the boats with sniffer dogs and all the other forms of investigative material that are available to them but also going to the homes of some of these retailers and fishermen in the Wollongong area and at Warrawong and in other parts of the Illawarra. They forced their way into these people's homes and, I might say, frightened the life out of the families of these fishermen and the retailers of fishing products in the Illawarra, all on the say-so of AFMA.

I took this issue up when it was brought to my attention. The cooperation I received at the time from Minister Vanstone's office and the then customs minister Mr Truss was very much appreciated. Staff from both of those offices gave me some advice which I subsequently conveyed to the fishermen in question. The stigma that still surrounds this particular event—the fact that sniffer dogs, normally associated with some form of investigation into illicit narcotic trafficking, were used—has left a lasting impression in the Italian and Greek communities of Wollongong.

Regrettably, it is not a good impression. The impression that has been left is that these fishing families who have been in operation in Wollongong and the Illawarra for years and years and years—families like the LaMacchias, the Musumicis and retailers like the Condakis family—have been involved in illicit drug operations. As a consequence, they have been unfairly and unjustly targeted.

Madam Acting Deputy Speaker Crosio, you would appreciate that, if you lived in a community like the Illawarra where there are a number of ethnic groups who have chosen to make Wollongong their home and people that belong to those communities socialise together, go to church together and so on, if there is any hint of suspicion about one of their number, then it is something which brings some shame to members of those families under suspicion.

My investigations at the time revealed that this particular activity was actually authorised by the Australian Fishing Management Authority. In discussions with both the AFP and the ACS, I was told that it was part of normal ongoing investigations. I was told that there was some concern that the fishing vessels were going out but not coming back with the quantities of fish which would seem to indicate that they were engaged in legitimate fishing activities. It may well have been that the fish were not running on that particular visit out to sea and, as a consequence, naturally, they did come back empty handed or certainly not with the quantities that some might otherwise have expected.

I was clearly advised by the ministers' offices collectively that it was not part of any investigation into drug running. I am also informed that Minister Vanstone had not really authorised this particular activity. I would like clarified whether that is the case. I would like clarified and I would like some statement to come from the government as to whether or not there was some implication about drugs and whether the minister's office—in this case, Minister Vanstone's office—had in fact authorised the activity of the Australian Federal Police in this particular search operation. Importantly, what I would like the ministers responsible to examine is whether or not this is part of an ongoing pattern of activity of harassment by AFMA because that organisation lost a couple of court cases to the Wollongong fishermen.

It would surprise me, as it surprises my friend the member for Leichhardt on the other side of the table, that a government bureaucracy would in any way want to conduct a vendetta against anybody in this community. But the information provided to me from the fishing co-op, from individual families in the Wollongong area and indeed from people involved in this particular matter has clearly indicated to me that the management plans that had been negotiated, the quotas that had been negotiated, the fact that there was disagreement over the years and the fact that there had been legal cases run against AFMA which AFMA had lost would seem to raise some suspicions that perhaps AFMA was engaged in some sort of vendetta against the fishing families of Wollongong.

These are people who have taken their rightful place in the local community over many years. I actually went to school with one of the families, the LaMacchias. That is how long they have been around Wollongong. They have been around that long that they went out in row boats when they first went out fishing. They are genuine families who have participated as part of the general community for a long, long time. But now there is this slur on their reputation. There is this implication that, in some way, they have been using their fishing vessels for some illegal activity involving drug running, as the implication first was put to them, which has certainly been disavowed in conversations with the ministers' offices.

It is time that these people at the very least were owed an explanation. They are owed an apology. They are also owed a clarification as to what the basis of this was. Information which I have to hand indicates that this is an issue that goes back even to our time in government. I can remember bringing delegations from Wollongong to see Simon Crean, the member for Hotham, when he was the minister for primary industries to discuss these sorts of issues. I can remember that we actually got to the bottom of many of the problems that the fishing fleet of Wollongong have.

It was always going to continue to be an ongoing issue involving scientific evidence about the size and the growth of individual species that were being fished in the waters of the Illawarra and beyond. As the fishermen themselves rightly point out, why would they want to overfish these waters when it is their own livelihood that depends on a real supply being maintained? Why would they want to go out and do this in contravention of their own livelihoods? I am afraid that, as I have said, AFMA have not been able to accept many of these assurances that have been given.

I again reiterate that it does strike me as strange that ministers or ministers' offices have given me assurances about why this operation was undertaken—at the behest of AFMA—yet there was no indication of anything illegal as we know. The fact that all of the documents and so on were seized and families' homes were raided does smack of a bit of a vendetta. I reiterate that I would like to see the government and the ministers concerned investigate this issue. I will certainly be asking them to do that again. An apology should be forthcoming. If it is from AFMA, then that is fine. But I think AFMA should get off the backs of those fishermen in the local area, let them get on with making their own livelihoods and stop sullying their reputations.

talk.start.para: —I wish to raise in the House an issue of extreme importance to my electorate of Page. That issue relates to the decision last week by the Carr Labor government in New South Wales to declare another round of national parks and wilderness areas over forest areas on the north coast of New South Wales. As you, Madam Deputy Speaker Crosio, would recall, when we were both members of the state parliament this issue raised its head from time to time. In 1984 the Premier of a government you were a member of—the Premier then was Neville Wran—made a decision on this rainforest area which he believed at the time would put to rest the debate between forestry and national parks and wilderness. He said that he was setting aside these areas in New South Wales to ensure that the remainder would be available for the forest industries as an ongoing resource. This debate has never gone away and continues to simmer.

speech.para: The problem we have is that the environmental movement continue to pursue what they believe is the locking up of all native forest areas in Australia—to the detriment, I might say, of the Australian economy. If you look closely at the imports of forest products last year, you will find some $3 billion was accredited to that. Many of these products come from unsound practices in developing countries, particularly clear-felling, sometimes in tropical rainforests. Our exports of chips were worth some $600,000, so the net deficit to Australia was $2.4 billion.

In my area and particularly around Grafton, which is the biggest hardwood timber area in New South Wales and Australia, this is of great importance to employment and to the industries that that industry supports. The present round raises the area of national park in New South Wales to 68 per cent of the area available for forestry in that state. It reduces the quota that was available to the timber milling industry from 320,000 cubic metres per year to 140,000 cubic metres per year.

The government and some members of the sawmilling fraternity are putting forward the suggestion that this is a good result. I put to you that it is a very poor result as far as Australia, and particularly the workers in a very high unemployment area such as the north coast of New South Wales, is concerned. If you look closely at the loss of quota in that area and the amount of timber that could reasonably be expected to be recovered under that quota, and then multiply out a value-added product to that, you would see that something like $40 million a year in resources—and the wages of people who could be working in that industry—are being lost to New South Wales and Australia.

This has been very cleverly orchestrated because, with the announcement by the Keating government of a national forest policy statement, the present government put forward that they would pursue that and continue with that. But you might recall that the Prime Minister also said very clearly that, in those instances where this would have very serious effects on low socioeconomic groups, he would not slavishly stick to the 15 per cent of species pre-1750. `Pre-1750', which is supposedly before Europeans came to this country, is an interesting statement because how do you judge exactly what forest was available at that time?

The only records we have are those that are available from the journals of explorers. If you look closely at those, you will find that the forests that we have today are much better than the forests that were available pre European settlement of this country. The reasons for that are very simple. The Aborigines in this country used fire extensively and, because the forests were burnt on a regular basis, practically yearly, the young trees were not able to reproduce like they do today in a very managed environment.

I think it was the explorer Oxley going up the Hunter River who commented in his diary that for 20 miles each side of the river there were grasslands. Yet today national parks and wildlife people would suggest to us on computer modelling that, with the soils in those areas and the rainfall, all of these areas were covered in forests. Therefore, the whole process is distorted by these assumptions that are being made by present-day people who do not recall clearly what the forests were in the period pre or even when Europeans first came to this country.

The problem we have is that some millers who have been able to access funds from the FISAP process, the forest industry structural adjustment package, have now locked themselves in. Some of them were granted up to $1 million to ostensibly upgrade their equipment, yet they are producing only the same product they were producing before. So this story that we are getting value-added product is a myth. We are producing only the same as we did before, but these people have been granted up to $1 million. The problem is that they have also borrowed money themselves—up to $2 million and $3 million—so they are completely locked into this process. But there are only a few of those.

In my particular area I can understand those people who are trying to protect their investment. There are two mills in my area in that situation. On the other side of things, there are about 30 small mills in the area which we call bush mills. Interestingly, they employ more people than the automated mills in the bigger industries. There is a loss of resource to those mills. Even though the mills that have got money from the FISAP process and have been supported by the state government employ large numbers of people, it is the smaller mills outside which employ more people which are completely cut off.

The forest industry adjustment process has failed. I know of people who have been forced completely out of the industry without compensation. I know employees who have been made redundant and have not had available to them the retraining or the redeployment that was supposedly available in this process. Those people have just been swept aside. No-one is listening to them, either the employees out of the mills or those people who are mixed up in the harvesting and haulage of the timber to the mills. They have been pushed aside. They have lost their entire investment. Hundreds of thousands of dollars have been completely lost without any compensation.

I believe that the process in New South Wales has been rushed for political reasons. The science involved has not been explored. The socioeconomic effects of these decisions certainly have not been taken into consideration. There is no doubt in my mind that the New South Wales government, despite what has been said in the press, has been completely manipulated by the extremist environment movement, which is out there crying crocodile tears over the fact that they have not got all of the resource—they have got almost 50 per cent of it but they haven't got all of it—but this is an act that has been put on before, after negotiations have taken place behind closed doors.

It is interesting to me that the CMFEU are standing against this position. They believe the same as I do—that the workers and the industry have been sold out, that positions that would have been available to their work ers will no longer be available. They are standing up strongly on this against the Carr government because they think it is an injustice. Added to this is the fact that there are grazing leases involved. These people have had their property rights confiscated in a scandalous way.

talk.start.para: —It sounds like native title.
—This is what the Labor Party does. The member for Banks might listen—(Time expired)
—We will debate that at another time. The time for grievances has now expired. The debate is interrupted and I put the question:

debateinfo.title: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1998 (No. 2)

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

talk.start.para: —Before I call the honourable member for Capricornia, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech. I ask the House to extend to her the usual courtesies.

—I rise to speak for the first time in this place with a great sense of responsibility to the people of Capricornia who put me here. I stand here also with a sense of purpose. Capricornia is a long way from Canberra. It is a long way for me to travel just to occupy a seat. I need to use my time here effectively for the people of Capricornia and make every day count. The views and hopes and ideals that I hold and that I hope to advance during my time here are those that I presented to the people of Capricornia during the recent campaign. Those values and beliefs are a product of both my working-class background and my experience of growing up, working and living in a regional area of Australia.

speech.para: Looking back, I guess you could say that I had a very sound education in Labor values and ideals starting at an early age. It was an education based on theory as well as some pretty solid practical experience. In my family it was unavoidable. It was a family in which the Labor Party was as much a part of everyday life as vegemite sandwiches and backyard cricket. In his home town of Ipswich, my father Ian was surrounded by a family of coalminers and railway workers. Similarly, my mother's family had a history of working in the central Queensland gold mines, at places like Mount Morgan and Mount Chalmers. They knew that it was the Australian Labor Party that looks after working people and their families. It is not surprising, therefore, that one of my earliest memories in life is a rally led by that great Labor bloke Tom Burns that I attended with my parents to protest the shameful dismissal of the Whitlam government on the day after my sixth birthday.

The reforms of the Whitlam government had a big impact on my working-class family and many others like it. Suddenly, ordinary people could expect things like affordable health care, a university education for their children and, in the case of my parents, a society that would offer the same opportunities to my sisters and me as our male classmates.

This has always been the centre of the Labor Party ethos: the idea that there should be a fair go for everyone regardless of birthplace, birth date or birthright. We certainly put those principles to the test in my family. I am pleased to say that the Labor Party passed the test. I was 11 when my father died. My mother found herself with the job of providing emotionally and financially for her three young daughters, the youngest of whom was only six. I have never forgotten the short trip from working class to welfare class, a trip that many Australians have shared for what ever reason. It is a trip that no-one in my family asked for but nonetheless had to endure. The Labor Party passed the test. It is the test that it sets for itself. It espouses the principles of a fair go and equality of opportunity. Thanks to the assistance available to struggling families under the Hawke and Keating governments, my sisters and I never had to let go of the aspirations planted in our minds during Whitlam's time.

It was this experience that shaped my views on fairness. It was this lesson of how indiscriminately life can come along and kick you in the guts that brought me in touch with others in the same situation. It was during those difficult years that I made up my mind to work hard so that I would some day be in a position to fight for those same principles that helped my family so much. That decision led me to politics and inevitably to the Australian Labor Party. There was only one party that advocated on behalf of my family. There has only ever been one political organisation that dealt with the issues of fairness and equity. There is only one: the political arm of the labour movement in Australia, the Australian Labor Party.

I am a Labor member of parliament for the reasons I have just described. I am the member for Capricornia because Central Queensland is my home and it is the part of Australia that I care about and want to pour my heart, energy and aspirations into. It is an honour and an exciting challenge to represent the electorate of Capricornia in this place. The electorate of Capricornia extends from the beautiful Capricorn Coast and Shoalwater Bay on the Central Queensland coast to the awesome expanse of the outback and towns such as Winton, Muttaburra, Longreach, Barcaldine, Aramac, Jericho and Alpha. It also includes the mining towns of the Bowen Basin, such as Moranbah, Dysart, Tieri, Middlemount, Cappella, Clermont and Glenden and Collinsville, which is a town that has a particularly strong Labor heritage. The major city of my electorate is my home of Rockhampton.

Capricornia is indeed an enormous electorate with a spirit to match. It is an electorate full of character as well as its fair share of characters. The electorate of Capricornia has a proud history that belongs to both the traditional owners of our region and to those of us who have made it our home. It is not a history of purely academic interest but a living history, because the products of that history endure today as important symbols and institutions of our country. I am talking of things such as Qantas, which was conceived at a meeting in Winton and launched from a dusty airstrip in Longreach. Waltzing Matilda was written at Dagworth station and first performed at the North Gregory hotel in Winton.

Of course there is the Australian Labor Party. The architects of the last redistribution perhaps would not have known the historical significance of the lines they drew. In fact, the boundary of the Capricornia electorate covers Clermont, Barcaldine and Rockhampton. All three centres played a significant role in Labor history. The Ballad of 1891, a long-held hymn of the working class, especially in Queensland, tells it all with lines such as:
From Clermont to Barcaldine the shearers' song rang out—the sheds'll be shore union or they won't be shore at all.
There is also:

To trial at Rockhampton the 14 men were brought. The judge had got his orders—the squatters owned the court. But for every man that was sentenced a 1000 won't forget—where you jail a man for striking it's a rich man's country yet.

No doubt some of my colleagues will want to argue this point and claim that the birthplace of our party is Sydney or Melbourne. However, the tree of knowledge in Barcaldine stands as a testament to the claim that the Australian Labor Party was born in Capricornia.

There can, however, be no dispute about the statement that Capricornia boasts many wonderful achievements. Wool grown on the backs of our sheep out west and shorn by local shearers such as John Laffin finds itself woven into the highest quality suits. Beef mustered out of the gullies and downs from Winton to Westwood, from Longreach to Lockington and from Aramac to Alton Downs graces the best dining tables in the world and gives my home of Rockhampton its much deserved title of the beef capital of Australia.

Coal dug from Capricornia's soil by hardworking coalminers makes our region one of Australia's richest exporters. The Central Queensland University is a progressive and successful institution that provides high quality educational and research facilities to our region and beyond as well as playing a leading role in our community. Great Keppel Island and the towns of the spectacular Capricorn Coast welcome increasing numbers of Australian and international tourists each year. Just up the road is Shoalwater Bay, a training area used by our Australian armed forces and one that regularly hosts exercises with our neighbours, such as the Singaporeans who have spent the last couple of months training there.

There is no doubt that our region of Central Queensland has great potential to build on our fine history. I wonder, though, whether this government knows what it is doing to crush the traditional spirit of the people of Capricornia. When I listen to people in the communities around the electorate, I share their feeling that this government has abandoned us in regional Australia. The coalition government apparently sees no role for itself in ensuring that the gains made by our country and the standard of living available to Australians are evenly distributed. The No. 1 issue for us in Capricornia has to be jobs: creating new jobs and providing security for those in work.

So what does the Howard government give us? It gives us an industrial relations regime that threatens the wages, conditions and security of workers and cutbacks to the public sector in our region. I spoke before about the history of Capricornia being a living history. There were parts of that history that we thought would never have to be relived: the times in our history when workers were gaoled and denied livelihoods for themselves and their families simply because they were members of a union. It appears that those times are alive and well in Capricornia. Just ask my mate Garry Barnes, the president of the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union in Clermont, one of 16 unionists at the Blair Athol coalmine currently engaged in an unfair dismissal claim against Rio Tinto after losing their jobs shortly after refusing to sign individual contracts.

I have stood shoulder to shoulder with miners on picket lines around Capricornia while they struggle against the government's ideological allies, like Rio Tinto and Arco, to protect their jobs and that most basic right of workers, the right to form a union and bargain collectively. I have stood in the smoko rooms at the meatworks in Rocky and listened to the workers there talk about their fears of the future in a workplace where the award has been stripped back to nothing.

When the government talks of union members, it seems that it regards them as some kind of breed apart from the rest of society. The government's narrow ideological view of the world does not let it see that union members cannot be cleanly removed from a workplace with some kind of surgical precision without there being residual damage to a community. I am thinking in particular of the mining towns in Capricornia. The union members who are being attacked there are my friends, and I know them to be the local footy coaches, scout leaders and school P&C presidents. They have wives and children. They are the people who spend their pay packets on groceries and Christmas presents at the local businesses. You cannot attack these people without attacking the whole community.

It is not only the government's industrial relations policies that are hurting Capricornia. Over the past two years we have also seen the decline of government services in our region. We have seen the Taxation Office close in Rocky and Telstra workers retrenched. When the CES office closed in Longreach, there was nothing there with which to replace it. The people of Capricornia need these services just as much as those living in capital cities need them.

It is the regional areas that suffer the most from the government's agenda of downsizing and privatising because the market that is supposed to fill the gaps is not interested in us. We cost too much and eat up profits. We rely on the government taking some responsi bility for keeping our communities functioning and providing services to those who need them.

The government is clearly not listening to people in regional areas. If it were listening, it would not have announced two weeks ago that we can expect more job losses at our local Centrelink office. The sick and disabled, the unemployed and the elderly people of Capricornia know exactly what that means for them—a decrease in services. The business people of Capricornia know exactly what it means for them too—fewer pay packets in our towns to keep our local economy ticking over.

In Capricornia we have seen the same thing over and over—promises of increased competition and efficiency that amount to nothing but the slashing of jobs and the decline of services. Whether it is the sale of Telstra or the deregulation of Australia Post, the message from my electorate is clear.

I have wasted no time in bringing these issues into this chamber because they are the issues that I campaigned on and they are the issues that the people of Capricornia expect me to pursue on their behalf. Wherever I go in the electorate—whether it be the Rocky railway workshops, the Lakes Creek meatworks, the Longreach RSL, the Middlemount Bowls Club or Pat Ogden's Globe Hotel—the people of Capricornia have had a gutful of economic policies that are advocated by people who have never even heard of Alpha or Jericho or St Laurence. The people of Capricornia are not interested in fitting into anyone's economic model; they want to be proud of their local communities and not feel penalised because they do not live in the city.

Most of the things that I will say in this place will be spoken on behalf of the people of Capricornia. Right now, though, I would like to say a few words that are mine alone, and they are words that come from the bottom of my heart. I want to pay tribute to the people who gave so much of themselves to get me here. I will never forget or take for granted the support and assistance that I received from local ALP branch members in Capricornia—people like Robert Schwarten and Barry Large and their families; people like Bronco Smith, Marilyn Tynan, Sam Morris, Jim Pearce, Pat Ogden, Stephen Schwarten, Jeff Jones and Mary Therese Brady.

It was especially touching for me to have the support of the family of the late George Gray, the member for Capricornia from 1961 to 1967. Thank you to Bray, Linda, Trish, Jeanne, Don and Rick. One branch member, Joan Brady, deserves a special thank you for being there right from the start. Thank you, Joan, for having faith in a 27-year-old woman long before anyone else got quite used to the idea.

My local branch members have a dedication to their party and a commitment to their communities that I hope I can live up to. From its inception, the Labor Party has been the political voice of the union movement; I will certainly continue that role as the member for Capricornia. During the campaign my brothers and sisters in the union movement showed that they truly understand the meaning of solidarity. The support from unions—like the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union; the Australian Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union; the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union; the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union; the Queensland Nurses Union; the National Tertiary Education Union; the Communications, Electrical and Plumbing Union; my old employer, the Community and Public Sector Union; and others—was absolutely rock solid and an important part of Labor's victory in Capricornia. I would also like to pay tribute to the members of Emily's List for their support and motivation throughout my time as a political candidate.

It does feel sometimes that the Labor Party has become my family—it has become such a big part of my life—but it can never compare to the wonderful family that has given me so much love and support over the last 29 years of my life. Thank you to my mother, Desley, and my sister Heidi, who is here today, and my little sister Sascha. My grandparents—Richard and Beryl White in Mackay, and Roy and Clara Livermore in Ipswich—also played a big part in giving me the values and motivation to make this journey.

Compared with these people, my partner, Craig Brown, is a relative newcomer. But the last 3½ years that he has shared with me have been the most tumultuous and fulfilling of my life: you're my best mate—I couldn't have done it without you, and I wouldn't have wanted to.

I finish today with a pledge to work my heart out for the people of my electorate. As the member for Capricornia, I will work with the communities in the electorate to build on our traditional strengths and always be on the lookout for new opportunities for our region. I cannot promise miracles, but I promise hard work, determination and complete honesty of conviction in trying to deliver to the people of Capricornia a secure future.

talk.start.para: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Capricornia, spoke very eloquently and very movingly. It was somewhat distressing that she had not done a little more study—

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable member for Kennedy has the floor. He will examine his own conscience at a later date.

—Yes, that is correct. I appreciate young people having their dreams and their aspirations. I think that is an important thing, but let me say that in Queensland when 23,000 railwaymen stood in the hot sun and handed out how to vote cards for the ALP they believed in that organisation. Within four years of their great party gaining office in the state of Queensland, there were not 23,000 of them; there were 14,000 of them. In the last 10 years of the government of which I was a part—and I take great pride in saying this—we lost 1,000 jobs in the railway. They went from 23,000 to 22,000. In the first four years of Labor 22,000 railwaymen became 13,000. If those little towns are dying at the moment, it is because those services were removed by the Labor government. In fact, the people of western Queensland created the labour movement and what we got for it was the destruction of our own homeland.

speech.para: An interesting analogy can be drawn from the comments of the last speaker. She said that Mr Whitlam was the person who got her into parliament, and that was also true of me because Mr Whitlam got me into parliament. She spoke about the right and the ability to be able to get her way to university. I think there was some merit in what occurred there. In my day I went to university. I went to university because I went home after I finished school and worked 72 hours a week. I worked from nine to five in my father's clothing shop, and then in the evening I worked at our picture theatre six nights a week. I worked very hard and saved up to go away to university.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! I can understand and appreciate the exuberance coming from the opposition benches, but I have given the call to the honourable member for Kennedy. He will be heard in silence.

—It obviously hurts them, Madam Deputy Speaker. I can understand the pain. As for what we did, every single thing that the previous speaker described was not done by the current government at all. Enterprise bargaining was not introduced by us. Enterprise bargaining, which undermined the right of the worker to collectively bargain, was introduced by Mr Keating. Who was it who flew foreign scabs to strikebreak into this country and gave them fast visas to be able to do it? It was not this government; it was the Keating government. Who removed all the tariffs in this country?

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am talking about the pilots. Are you saying that this is incorrect? Of course you are not. You agree with it, but you would not be game to say it. The economic rationalists were not on this side of the House. All of that legislation was introduced by those on that side of the House when they were sitting on this side of the House.

speech.para: Let me turn to the removal of services. I can hardly think of a town where there has not been a massive removal of services. I have at times been critical of the Borbidge government in Queensland, but I cannot think of a single service that it removed in my old state electorate of Flinders. Yet in my own home town of Cloncurry there were six services removed.

talk.start.para: —You want to bring back Bjelke-Petersen, do you? Are you a `Joh for PM' man?
—I will answer your question by saying that we took 1,000 railway jobs away in 10 years; your mob took 10,000 jobs away in 3½ years. You should not have walked into that one, should you?

speech.para: I would like to draw to the attention of this House the suicide rate in this country. From 1971 to 1996 male suicides in this country have doubled, and for young men they have increased by some 300 per cent. Australia is now second only to Russia, which has the highest suicide rate for young men in the entire world. Unemployment in 1971 was 1.7 per cent. Unemployment in Australia today is 7.7 per cent, some 700 per cent higher than it was in 1971. I have some figures on the growth in our gaols in Queensland. I do not have the figures for Australia as a whole. In 1971 there were 1,236 in our gaols. In 1996 there were 3,528 people, an increase of some 300 per cent. Even more amazing is the rise in bankruptcies. In 1971 there were 2,428 bankruptcies. Today in Australia bankruptcies total 24,000.

The previous speaker attributed all the ills in this country to the current government. I am afraid that over the last 15 years we have been in government for only 2½ years. If there are a lot of ills in this country, she should take it up with her current leadership, all of whom were on the frontbench during the period when bankruptcies in Australia rose from about 4,500 to some 20,000. The policies that they put in train during those years are still crucifying the country today. It will be some years before the effects of those policies abate.

Having looked at those grim statistics and having reflected upon the fact that small business in Australia is almost a vanishing and dying race, I would like to quote but one example. There were 17,000 privately owned service stations in Australia before Mr Keating—the great architect of economic rationalist policy in this place—decided to half-deregulate the service stations. He half-deregulated the service stations, and the net result was that 8,000 family businesses in this country ceased to exist. They went broke and closed their doors.

We are talking not only about heartbreak and destruction here but also about an increase in control in the marketplace by the oil companies. From 1984 to the present day, we have seen a rise in the price of petrol paid to the oil companies from 12c a litre in 1984 to around 22c a litre today—almost a doubling of the price paid to the oil companies for petrol. In that same period of time, the price for a barrel of oil has dropped from around $38 to about $15 or $16. So the world price has dropped clean in half and the price in Australia has doubled. Clearly, the cost to the nation of that act of deregulation has been colossal.

We look for reasons as to why we have a horrific 300-fold increase in the number of people in our gaols and a 250 per cent increase in the number of young male suicides. The previous speaker, the member for Capricornia, gave a very sensitive and a very good address, but I would ask people in these cases: if you are going to stand up and put forward propositions, back them up. It is not good enough to come in here and just make some bland statements without hard factual evidence to back them up.

I have a gold file here with me, and I can give the source document for each of the figures that I am quoting here. The graph on page 28 of the document I have here tells the story on unemployment, unhappiness and sadness in this country. There is a graph showing the growth in unemployment amongst young males from 1966 to 1996, and there is a similar graph for the growth in the suicide rate amongst that same cohort of population from 1966 to 1996. It is a truly remarkable document, because the graphs cannot be separated; they are almost identical. The rise in unemployment amongst young males has been identical to the rise in youth suicides in this country. So, if you are looking for an answer for all of this dreadful unhappiness, look no further than jobs.

When people like Mr Whitlam reduced tariff protection by 25 per cent across the board, it cost Australia hundreds of thousands of jobs and burnt out so much opportunity that could have existed in this country. I am not saying that there was not a case for reducing tariffs, and I am not saying that there was not a case for reducing tariffs significantly. But to hit them with a blunt instrument of 25 per cent, and then proceed—in the years of the Hawke-Keating government—to remove all tariffs, was one of the greatest examples of supine trading policy espoused by any country anywhere in the world. I see the honourable member for Dickson grinning. I am sure that she would agree with everything I am saying here, as she has on many occasions.

It can well be argued that economic rationalism, and the removal of all of those protections, was a good thing internationally. But, unfortunately, the other countries in the world have not done that. To take the example of one of the industries I represent, the tariff on sugar has been completely removed, and that allows the biggest sugar exporter in the world, the European Community, to send its sugar into Australia with a subsidy equivalent to 193 per cent.

We have been given little talks about free trade in this place during the four years that I have been in here and in the 12 years before that, two of which were under Mr Keating. They did not cut much ice with me, as a person who has owned cattle all of my adult life. I was not very convinced, because only 7,000 tonnes of beef are allowed into the European Community—a market of arguably 500 million or 600 million people. One of my neighbours—one person in Australia—would produce 7,000 tonnes a year. A number of people will each produce more than 7,000 tonnes of beef a year. Yet we have played fair game while the other side have played snake and goannas. They must be laughing at us.

The previous speaker attributed to this government decisions it had nothing to do with. All of those decisions were taken prior to this government taking office. We could not remove any tariffs, because there were no tariffs left to remove. There was nothing left for us to do. She said that we are grinding the worker down. But enterprise bargaining was introduced by the previous government. If the worker is being ground down as a result of enterprise bargaining, we had nothing to do with that. And she said that any further action taken by us will worsen this situation. But enterprise bargaining is here now. We can do whatever needs to be done, but it will not have much effect, because it already exists.

In the seven minutes left, I would like to quickly go through the solutions. We have this horrific suicide rate and we have this terribly high unemployment rate, and I cannot help but make the point to the House that David Kemp, when he was opposition spokesman on employment, quoted the real unemployment figure at around 19 per cent—and he had a breakdown of that figure. I thought that was a very good analysis. The OECD report on employment in Australia gives similar figures. Dr John Langmore, who was a member of parliament for some time—in fact he was chairman of the caucus economics committee of the Labor Party—also quoted a figure of around 19 per cent. John Quiggan, the only economist in Australian history to get the Academy of Science prize, also quoted a figure of 19 per cent.

I will tell you how that is arrived at. There were 56,000 people on the CDEP program. These people were taken off the dole and put on a work for the dole scheme in Aboriginal settlements throughout Australia. There were some 200,000 people on Working Nation, and similar schemes have come in. And that is a good thing; I am not criticising them for one moment.

Quiggan and Langmore both make the point that TPI pensions in Australia have increased by 400 per cent. This is undoubtedly true, and I suppose there would be very few of us who do not know people with bad backs—but they do a lot of work at home during the week with their bad backs. I do not blame them for that; I just think that there are no jobs out there for them.

What I am saying is that the real figures are much higher than the indicative figures that we have before us at all times, and I think that David Kemp's analysis in this parliament deserves some looking at by people on both sides of this House if they want to get a true understanding of the nature of unemployment in this country.
There is one thing that this current government has done which has been absolutely magnificent, and it should never be underestimated. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debateinfo.title: TELSTRA (TRANSITION TO FULL PRIVATE OWNERSHIP) BILL 1998

cognateinfo.title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS (CONSUMER PROTECTION AND SERVICE STANDARDS) BILL 1998
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (CONSUMER PROTECTION AND SERVICE STANDARDS) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Mr Fahey:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Labor opposes the full privatisation of Telstra and, as a consequence, opposes the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 and the package of cognate legislation now before the House. We oppose the package because it effects the full privatisation of Telstra. It effects it through a sham inquiry; it effects it through sleight of hand; it effects it through maximum damage to rural and regional Australia—and the National Party should be ashamed that they have sat on their hands since the election, sat on their hands in the joint party room and done nothing to stand up for the interests of rural and regional Australia—and that includes the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Mr Vaile, who is at the table, and some of the new members of the National Party who have now fled the chamber.

speech.para: In particular, this applies to the members for Dawson and Kennedy—who, in the run-up to the last election, made great play of standing up for the interests of rural and regional Australia and made great play of the fact that they did not want to see Telstra fully privatised. I notice that they are on the list of speakers, and so I hope that, when they come and make their contributions, the member for Kennedy and the member for Dawson will create the same impression in this House as they created in their electorates in the run-up to the election: in other words, that they oppose the full privatisation of Telstra and cross the floor on the bill.

I assume that, at the joint party meeting at which government members approved this legislation, when National Party members saw the senior Liberal Senator from Tasmania they said, `Dr Watson, I presume', because Senator Watson from Tasmania has been the only member of the coalition since the election—the only member—to say the truth about this package of measures. He said on 8 November in Tasmania that he did not believe that Telstra ought to be fully privatised, and he was reported on the ABC on 8 November as saying that there was majority support in the coalition for limiting further privatisation of Telstra.

He said that the government needed to develop more of a social conscience during this term of office, and that there was widespread community concern about the ability of a fully privatised Telstra to maintain its community service obligations to regional and remote areas. I repeat: `widespread community concern' about the ability of a fully privatised Telstra to maintain its community service obligations to regional and remote areas—areas that the National Party purports to represent.
On the following day, 9 November, in the Australian Financial Review, Senator Watson's attitude was reported thus:

In a further embarrassment to the Government, Senator Watson also cast doubt on whether Telstra would be fully privatised in the foreseeable future. He said his position against a full sale had sufficient support from his government colleagues to ensure it did not go ahead.
This is despite Mr Howard being committed to a full sale of Telstra.

He was also reported as saying that `he saw no reason to move from the 49 per cent sale of Telstra' and that `this position had enough support among his colleagues to ensure there was no full sale in the foreseeable future.'

Well, they all disappeared at the joint party room meeting; they all disappeared. And when the members for Kennedy and Dawson come into this chamber, I hope they stand up for their electorates and stand up for the sorts of comments they made in the run-up to the election.

talk.start.para: —Were you at the party room meeting?

—The point is, Minister, you were there and you did not stand up for rural and regional Australia. You did not stand up for your constituents. You did not stand up for the people that you purport to represent.

speech.para: Labor opposes this package. Labor would not have privatised one-third of Telstra, as the government did in the previous parliament. In the run-up to the 1996 election, we made it clear that we opposed the privatisation of Telstra. In the run-up to the 1998 election, we made it clear that we opposed any further sale beyond the one-third that the government disposed of in the course of the last parliament. So Labor has always been opposed, and remains opposed, to the sale of Telstra, and it will not support the sale of any further portion of Telstra, because primarily we believe that Telstra is a vital part of Australia's community, of our economy and of our regional infrastructure.

There are a number of major reasons why it is essential, in our view, for Telstra to remain in public ownership. Firstly, it is a question of national infrastructure, of economic development and jobs. It is clear that Telstra is a very important part of our national infrastructure. It is very important to our economic development and very important to jobs, particularly for rural and regional and remote Australia. And that lies at the heart of our opposition to the package of measures before the House today.

The second reason is that of the dividend which Telstra pays to the Commonwealth. Each year, Telstra generates a return, and those moneys are paid directly to benefit the taxpayer. By keeping Telstra in public hands, the Commonwealth will continue to receive these funds—funds which will grow each year into the future. Once you have flogged it off, you will not get that return in the future: you lose the profit stream that you have built up over a number of years. Once you have flogged it off, it has gone forever, and so that dividend which has been built up over many years and which provides important revenue to the Commonwealth for essential services generally but also essential services for rural and regional Australia will be gone.

The third reason is the services that Telstra provides to rural and regional and remote Australia: essential—and in many cases, historically, uneconomic—services provided to rural and regional Australia, because Australians and parliaments and governments in the past regarded Telstra, or its predecessor, Telecom—or Telecom's predecessor, the PMG—as being essential because people in rural and regional Australia would rely upon Telstra for their telecommunications services. Telstra is the dominant service provider and, if you keep Telstra in public hands, the government retains the right to ensure that adequate service levels and access to up-to-date technology are delivered to all Australians, irrespective of where they live. This is part of the universal service obligations and the community service obligations.

Keeping Telstra in public hands will make sure that, with the move to new technology, we minimise rather than maximise the tyranny of distance, making sure that we do not run the risk of alienating people who live in rural and remote locations in Australia, and that those who live in areas of Australia uneconomic to service have, and continue to have, access to the vital telecommunications services which Telstra has provided.

The next reason is the point of market dominance. There is no question that Telstra has significant market dominance in its area. You can probably mount the argument that the only thing worse than a public instrumentality which has market dominance is a private instrumentality which has market dominance.

Another reason is that historically the PMG and Telecom, in particular, and then Telstra have done public good works in their research activities. They have invested in long-term R&D. As a fully privatised company, they will not do basic research; they will not do the public good research. Already we have seen, in my view, a decline in that since the one-third privatisation.
