Another important factor is the significant support over the years which Telecom and Telstra have given to the Australian electronic and telecommunications manufacturing industries. There is a grave risk that that support over the years will decline and disappear if Telstra is fully privatised.

The whole focus of the privatisation of Telstra, which is reflected in this package of measures, is that Telstra will move from providing an adequate level of service to the Australian taxpayer to providing a dividend to its shareholders. That is reflected in very substantive terms by the proposed deletion from the Telstra Corporation Act of the capacity of the government of the day to instruct Telstra in accordance with the public interest.

So there are a range of general philosophical and practical reasons why we have opposed the privatisation of Telstra from day one. We opposed it in the run-up to the 1996 election, we opposed it in the parliament in this last term and we went to the election committed to opposing any further sale of Telstra.

This package of bills effectively fully privatises Telstra by sleight of hand. There is no doubt that in the run-up to the last election the government created the impression, both generally and in the various electorates, that if they were returned to office Telstra would be privatised in a staged way, and they unquestionably created the impression that that staging would be by parliamentary approval. Once passed, this package will effectively achieve the full privatisation of Telstra without further reference to this parliament. If parliament approves these bills, that automatically enables the Commonwealth to dispose of up to 49.9 per cent of Telstra and then, by a sham inquiry, without further reference to the parliament, without further reference to parliamentary review, to tick a box to effect the 100 per cent privatisation of Telstra.

It is important to have a look at some of the history. In 1996, when Telstra was in full public ownership, it brought in a profit of $2.2 billion and paid dividends of nearly $1.4 billion to the Commonwealth. That money was used for vital services and infrastructure such as hospitals, schools and nursing homes. As a consequence of the one-third privatisation, one-third of the profits are now directed away from the Commonwealth. Since the privatisation of Telstra, we have seen major restructuring of Telstra—effectively in preparation for full privatisation but also in response to the one-third privatisation—and that has had dramatic consequences for staffing and service levels. Approximately 22,000 employees have been shed and very many of those have been from rural, regional and remote areas.

Customer service standards are in decline. That is not an assertion. All you need to do is have a look at the December 1997 quarterly figures reported by the ACA, the Australian Communications Authority, to see the decline in standards which has occurred as a consequence of the one-third privatisation. There has been greater pressure for the imposition of additional charges for a range of services which Telstra provides—for example, directory assistance calls. All of these are reasons for Telstra remaining in public ownership.

The bills before us effect the full sale of Telstra. As I have said, if passed, these would allow automatically the sale of 49.9 per cent of Telstra and then effect the full privatisation without further reference to the parliament. Ministers Fahey and Alston in the run-up to the election unquestionably created the impression that this would be a package of legislation to sell up to 49.9 per cent and that the government would then come back to the parliament to effect the remaining sale. I am sure this is the impression they have left with their backbench, particularly the National Party backbenchers—or at least I am sure that is the impression the National Party backbenchers are happy to be left with. So it needs to be understood that if this bill passes the parliament then Telstra is gone. If this bill passes the parliament without further reference to the parliament, 100 per cent of Telstra will be disposed of—it will be gone forever.

Senator Alston promised in July when he announced on behalf of the government the so-called `staged disposal' that the staged approach was a consequence of concerns about service standards, particularly in rural, regional and remote Australia. He said:
. . . unless and until the independent inquiry certifies that service levels are adequate, there will be no further sell down beyond 49%.

It was on the strength of this that National Party members and candidates went out to their constituents and their electorates in the run-up to the 3 October election and effectively articulated that there would be a 49.9 per cent sell-off of Telstra before further activity. The member for Dawson, De-Anne Kelly, in August this year said:
People just really want to see Telstra remain in Government hands.
The bottom line is people don't want to see more than 49% sold.

Given that this legislation effects the full privatisation of Telstra, I hope when the member for Dawson comes into this chamber and speaks and when we divide on this package of measures, which we will, that she holds true to that particular comment and a range of other ones that she made in the run-up to the election and votes against these proposals. I have already drawn attention to the comments that Senator Watson from Tasmania made a few weeks ago. Of course there has been deafening silence from all the other members of the government.

I have described the so-called `independent inquiry' on the measures as a `sham inquiry'. The two relevant ministers—the Minister for Finance and Administration, Mr Fahey, and the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston— have always maintained that it was their intention to fully privatise Telstra. The Prime Minister has probably gone furthest of them all. On ABC radio on 27 July, in questioning on the supposed `independent inquiry', he was asked by an ABC reporter, `Is it conceivable that this inquiry would recommend that you don't sell the rest of Telstra and that you won't?' Howard: `No.'

So this is not an inquiry in respect of which the government has an open mind. This is not an inquiry in respect of which you can expect to see independent, impartial and objective assessment of these things. This is not an inquiry the results of which will be subject to review or determination at ministerial, cabinet or parliamentary level. In that same interview, the Prime Minister went on to say:
Well there's certainly been no flip-flop. I can't believe the description of last week's announcement as being a flip-flop. We are still committed to a sale of one hundred per cent of Telstra.
So it will not be an independent inquiry and it will not be a viable, rational or sensible inquiry. If the legislation has effect, it will be a six-month inquiry.

Whatever service levels are required—and these are not detailed in the legislation—you will be dealing with two quarters of data. In my view, two quarters of data is an insufficient period of time to establish any sort of realistic statistical trend. It is not enough to get an indication of Telstra's service performance, particularly for the bush. The ABS handles data on the basis that the only suitable basis for policy analysis or advice is data trend over five quarters or 15 months, which is described technically as the five-term Henderson moving averages technique.

So you have a massively inferior period of time over which data will be collected and assessed. And in the six-month period when Telstra would know they were under the spotlight, so to speak, it would be very easy for them to load up the respective services and, after the inquiry—after a six-month period—effectively let them all fall by the wayside.

So what do we find with respect to the so-called independent inquiry? The government has made it clear from day one that, irrespec tive of what the independent inquiry might say or do, it remains absolutely committed to the full privatisation of Telstra. Secondly, you will not have the period of time during which the data can be properly collected or assessed.

On the day of the announcement of the government's so-called staged sell-off—22 July—the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston, made a speech to the New South Wales Farmers Association Annual Conference, in the course of which he said:

The next thing the Government will do, in the same Bill, is specify performance criteria, against which Telstra's performance will be judged by an independent inquiry which the Government will establish . . . The criteria which will be contained in the legislation . . .

And you look in the legislation and you cannot find it. Having given a commitment, in the strongest possible terms on the day on which the policy was announced, that the bill would specify the performance criteria—that the criteria would be contained in this legislation—when you flick through the legislation you do not find it.

The criteria will be effected by regulation. You effect the full privatisation of Telstra by having this bill passed and then having a sham inquiry on criteria not seen by this parliament. You effect the full privatisation of Telstra by a sham inquiry working on the basis of regulations, despite an expressed and absolute commitment by the minister that those criteria would be contained in the legislation. And what do we hear from the National Party—Dr Watson, I presume—nothing; deafening silence. The inquiry is basically a sham. It is a tick the box. It is a rubber stamp. There is no reference back to the parliament, and they seek to slide this through without scrutiny.
I found an interesting quotation from the member for Kennedy, Mr Katter, which I am sure he will be only too happy to repeat to the House himself. During July-August, he said:

I must say that I thought it was a fairly arrogant statement and it most certainly indicated to me that they are determined not to withdraw in any way, shape or form . . . it seems to me their intention is that there will be some sort of rubber stamp committee to allow them to sell the second half. But I'm not going to go along with that, I can tell you right now.

All you need is the words of a member of this parliament, a member of the National Party: a `rubber stamp committee to allow them to sell the second half'. I hope the member for Kennedy comes into the parliament in the course of this week, repeats those comments and votes accordingly when the legislation is the subject of a division.

The package of legislation that the government envelopes around the sham inquiry has the government saying, `It will all be okay because we have a whole range of community obligations and consumer protection provisions that we have put in,' the vast bulk of which are status quo ante in any event. The government says it is okay and, `Look, this package is there to protect standards.' But all you need to do is look at the Australian Communications Authority performance monitoring data for the December 1997 quarter, which you find in the March 1998 Performance Monitoring Bulletin from the ACA, to find the decline of services that we have seen since Telstra was privatised by one-third—and don't expect that you would not see a similar or worse decline in services on the basis of a full privatisation.

Telstra's performance in the provision of new services in country areas declined by nine per cent to 66 per cent during the quarter ending 31 December 1997. This was a 16 per cent reduction on the quarter ending 31 December 1996. So you have a nine per cent decline following a 16 per cent decline. Telstra's performance in country areas in the number of faults cleared within one day also fell during the December 1997 quarter by seven per cent to 61 per cent, and this was a 13 per cent reduction on the December 1996 quarter. The percentage of faults cleared within two days fell by six per cent to 80 per cent during the December 1997 quarter, and by 10 per cent when compared with the December 1996 quarter.

The clearing of faults with payphones in country areas was even worse. The number of faults with public payphones which were cleared within one day fell by 14 per cent to 47 per cent during the December 1997 quarter and 20 per cent when compared with the December 1996 quarter.

Telstra explains each of these reductions in service usually in terms of organisational changes or inclement weathers, but even the minister for communications, Senator Alston, was forced to acknowledge that this performance was simply not good enough. So you find in the performance monitoring data of the ACA—the relevant regulatory authority—that there is a whole series of decline in services for country and rural and remote areas on the basis of a one-third privatisation of Telstra.

One of the important things that you lose with the package of measures that we find before the House and with the full privatisation of Telstra is the capacity of the government of the day or the minister of the day to intervene and direct Telstra in the national interest. There has been a very interesting history to this provision. The government in the previous parliament introduced its legislation to privatise one-third of Telstra in the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1996. It was introduced by the then member for Bass who is no longer with us—
Mr Martin interjecting—

talk.start.para: —He is no longer with us, but he is doing well. But I do not think he will pop up on this occasion as the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman.

speech.para: Mr Vaile interjecting—

talk.start.para: —He is in Sydney. Just like the National Party members in this parliament, he is not necessarily standing up to the Sydney and Melbourne lawyers at this point in the cycle. On 2 May in his second reading speech the then member for Bass said:

speech.para: The bill repeals the power contained in section 9 of the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 for the minister to give directions to Telstra in the national interest, from the date of sale of the first shares. Retention of the power post part sale would be overly intrusive and incongruous with moving Telstra into a more commercial framework.

So at the first opportunity this government sought to delete from the Telstra Corporation Act the power of the government of the day to instruct Telstra. Fortunately, through amendments moved on our behalf in the Senate and accepted ultimately by the government in this chamber, that power was reinstated and remains within the Telstra Corporation Act to this day.

This package of measures seeks to abolish it and seeks—again by sleight of hand—to create the impression that it is replaced with a somewhat comparable power. What it is actually replaced with is a very limited power, which is effectively a power on the part of a minister to require Telstra to comply with the law. What you lose is the capacity of the minister of the day to direct Telstra to do things which, in public policy terms, are in the public interest in the positive sense or to require Telstra to do things which are in the public interest in the negative sense by rectifying past wrongs or ill deeds.

So the very important capacity on the part of the Commonwealth to influence public policy is thrown out by the full privatisation of Telstra. And make no mistake, the full privatisation of Telstra and the removal of the power of the minister to direct in the public interest will see only one thing occurring: Telstra operating in a fully commercial way without regard to the sorts of historical obligations we have seen to rural, regional and remote Australia and without the sorts of obligations we have seen by way of community service obligations and universal service arrangements.

There are a couple of other points I might make in respect of the privatisation process. Under the legislation the privatisation process follows the same framework as the privatisation of one-third of Telstra—I note on the speakers' list that my colleague the member for Melbourne, the shadow minister for finance, is speaking as well; I am sure he will make great play of these points. The privatisation process for one-third of Telstra has been the subject of very ferocious, serious criticisms by the Auditor-General.

It is unquestionably the case from the Auditor-General's report that, if you do the calculations, the cost of the sale of one-third of Telstra effectively ran $65 million over budget, and excessive fees were paid to sales managers. The report highlighted a litany of administrative incompetence by the government which has been of direct benefit to sales managers. There is a cursory mention in the explanatory memorandum that these comments will be taken on board. That belied the demeanour and appearance of the Minister for Finance and Administration in question time last week when these things were put to him, where he did his best to effectively put his head in the sand and to ignore the fact that these deficiencies had occurred.

There are a number of measures in the legislation package which the government touts as being significant consumer protection or competition measures. But, in the main, these reflect the status quo ante; they are unremarkable and uncontentious. If dealt with in isolation separate from the ownership question, then they might easily be able to be seriously considered and generally agreed to. But because they form part of the veil of sham, of sliding through without effective scrutiny, creating the impression that this is a sale of 49 per cent of Telstra when it affects the full privatisation of Telstra, we are proposing to oppose the package in its entirety en bloc.

One of the measures in the Telstra bill itself is the suggestion to require the appointment of two members of the Telstra board who have rural and regional experience. That is the best concession the National Party could get out of the Melbourne and Sydney lawyers in this piece of legislation.

The real question here is, in a sense, the social obligations that historically we have seen with Telstra. The government says that a range of social bonuses will apply from the proceeds of the sale of Telstra. In the main, these last either as a one-off, over a period of three years or over a period of five years. After the five-year period is extinguished, what is the government going to do to ensure that uneconomic services continue to regions like the bush? There is no ministerial power to direct in the public interest. The one-off so-called social bonus from the proceeds has gone. It comes to a total of $671 million—not a sum to be sneezed at—but, in 1996, the last year of dividend returned to the government prior to the privatisation of Telstra, we saw a dividend of nearly $1.4 billion paid to the Commonwealth. So in the year before privatisation there was a dividend of $1.4 billion and now we find the so-called social bonus is some $671 million in total. If you spread that over a period of five years, you get an expenditure of about $134 million per year, which is about 10 or 11 per cent of the dividend that I have referred to.

Once the social bonus is gone, what is there to hold in place the services to rural, regional and remote Australia? Not a great deal. Senator Harradine from Tasmania has found in recent days the very grave difficulties of trying to make sure that promises, commitments and undertakings given in respect of jobs and services to an area like Tasmania are very hard to keep up to the mark once you unleash the privatisation forces. The capacity on the part of Senator Harradine or any other member of this House or the Senate to influence and affect Telstra will go out of the window with the full privatisation and the removal of the power to direct.
In the Australian of 13 November, I noticed a front page story by Mark Westfield entitled `Telstra sale threat' which reads:
Telstra's board might try to block the Federal Government's proposed further sale of shares in the carrier if the horse-trading over votes in the Senate threatens to damage the company commercially.

Then on page 21 Westfield in a comment piece goes into more detail and makes the point that the board is concerned about community service or universal obligations being placed on it. Nothing better could illustrate the dynamic and the difficulty of trying to keep in place the universal access arrangements and the community service obligations if this package of measures was enacted.

When we get down the speakers list to the members for Dawson and Kennedy, I hope we see them standing up and making the same sorts of comments they made to their constituents in the run-up to the last election. I hope they stand up and say, `We do not want to authorise a sale beyond 49 per cent.' I hope we see them cross the floor. This is a package of measures which effects the full privatisation of Telstra. It does it by a sham inquiry. It does it without effective reference to the parliament or review by the parliament. We oppose these measures absolutely. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —When members of the Labor Party stand up to speak in this debate, I hope they declare whether they took the opportunity to buy Telstra shares when the float was made. It would be very interesting to check the register of members' interests. I have not done so but I am sorely tempted. There are a few matters which in recent times have ignited emotions in regional and rural Australia more than the question of privatisation of Telstra. Let me make the position very clear from this side of the House: the proposed sale was not and is not motivated by ideology. No-one on this side of the House wants to sell Telstra for mere ideological reasons.

speech.para: The Prime Minister announced before the 1996 election, not after the election, that a coalition government would sell one-third of Telstra. We were open and honest about Telstra before the election. We did not make the announcement without a mandate, as Labor did with their plan to sell the Commonwealth Bank. Labor sold the Commonwealth Bank without a mandate. Not a word was said before the 1993 election about Labor's intention to sell the Commonwealth Bank. Labor sold the Commonwealth Bank by stealth. We sought a mandate from the Australian people before we sold one-third of Telstra, a mandate which the people gave us by the strongest acclamation—a resounding victory at the 1996 election.

This mandate was supported by the people of regional Australia. In the last parliament, the coalition held 61 seats which were wholly or partially rural or regional, as against the ALP's 11 seats. We had the one-third privatisation of Telstra firmly on the agenda. Although we had a mandate, Labor opposed the sale of Telstra and frustrated the passage of the legislation in the Senate.

I said that the coalition, in opposition and in government, were not driven by ideology in proposing to the Australian people that we partially privatise Telstra. Why would anybody sell an income producing asset? Why would an individual want to sell his or her income producing asset? Why would business people propose to sell their assets, especially income producing assets? Why would a government propose to sell an income producing asset? One obvious reason to sell an income producing asset is that you have to—not `want to' but `have to'.

What is being lost in this debate is that the government had little choice but to propose to sell Telstra if it were to be judged fiscally responsible. We had to pay off government debt. Remember that that debt was Labor's debt. Successive Hawke and Keating governments accumulated $95 billion of government debt in six or seven years during the 1990s. The stark reality is that Labor's debt had to be paid off. Some of it has been paid off but more remains to be paid off. Therefore, one reason to propose to sell an income producing asset is to retire debt. That point is reached when the cost of servicing that debt becomes unmanageable.

When we came to office, public debt interest was running at $9.1 billion. The member for Perth pointed out to the House that the income the government received through the dividend stream from Telstra was $1.4 billion. Debt servicing costs were $9.1 billion. In other words, our capacity to implement our programs—provide hospitals, health and other services—was limited by interest payments of over $9 billion on Labor's debt every year. Before we could spend one cent on social services—welfare, defence, roads—we had to spend $9.1 billion on interest payments on Labor's debt.

Another reason to propose to sell an income producing asset is to give yourself the financial capacity to invest in other income producing assets. The government has done a combination of these two things. We proposed before the 1996 election to sell one-third of Telstra because we were forced to address Labor's legacy of debt. We used part of the proceeds to retire a significant amount of that debt. The amount we did not use to pay off Labor's debt we have used for investment in national and regional development through the Federation Fund and the Natural Heritage Fund. Most of that $2 billion investment went into infrastructure and rebuilding rural and regional Australia.

After the sale of one-third of Telstra is Australia better off or worse off? Many Australians invested in the share float. Are they better off or worse off? Members on both sides of this House hold Telstra shares, and so they should. Everyone who invested in Telstra shares is better off today, including the employees of Telstra who had the opportunity to invest in the future performance of their employer. Are the people and the hundreds of regional communities that benefited from the excellent works funded from the Natural Heritage Fund and the Federation Fund worse off? I know they are not worse off. I know that local councils and communities are far better off from the investments made from the proceeds of the sale of the initial one-third of Telstra.

In the last budget in my previous capacity I tabled a statement on government expenditure in regional Australia which showed an annual expenditure of $3.2 billion on programs which were non-existent under the previous government—that is, $3.2 billion of expenditure in rural and regional Australia that was non-existent under the previous government. That was new expenditure, new programs and new investment creating new employment in the bush. This could not have been possible without the sale of one-third of Telstra. Would Australia have been better off without that quality infrastructure? Of course not. The reality is that without the sale of Telstra the government could not have funded the quality infrastructure so essential to the competitiveness of regional businesses and the quality of life for people living in rural and regional Australia.

I have already mentioned the $1 billion Federation Fund, the bulk of which contributes to national infrastructure. There is also a further $250 million through the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund and the Roads of National Importance program. The $1.25 billion Natural Heritage Trust is the most integrated and far-reaching package of investment in conservation and natural resource management ever introduced in Australia. We sold part of an income producing asset to retire Labor's debt and to invest in a whole range of other income and job producing assets, particularly in regional Australia.

Who then are the losers from the privatisation of Telstra? Who is worse off? Through scaremongering and misinformation, Labor has created a sea of unrest about the privatisation of Telstra. The implication of this and the doubt created by those such as One Nation is that people in regional Australia have been scared into believing that a full sale of Telstra would result in a fall in standards of service in the bush. When you look at the investment in the bush from the one-third sale of Telstra, people are far better off, not worse off. You can see where the money went and where the money is going. Interest on debt is down. Communication services in the bush have been boosted as never before.

I contrast this with Labor's record. They have opposed the sale of Telstra all the way with ideological passion. But Labor sold Qantas and Labor sold the Commonwealth Bank. What has Australia to show for the sale of these assets? Did Labor sell those income producing assets to pay off debt? The answer is an emphatic no. Debt went up during and after those sales, not down. Did Labor use the proceeds to invest in other income producing assets? The answer is again an emphatic no. In fact, not only did government debt accumulate further but Finance Minister Beazley left this government with a $10.3 billion budget deficit on top.

Labor sold Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank, but where did the money go? When we came to office we could not find it. There was no evidence that anyone benefited from Labor's privatisation program because Labor used the money not for investment, not for debt redemption; the proceeds propped up your budget bottom line. You blew the money and Australia has nothing to show for it. Proper economic management by the Howard government, the sale of one-third of Telstra and the responsible use of those proceeds see Australia far better off than in 1996.

I do not want to see further potential benefits disappear. The government will sell another 16 per cent of Telstra to keep faith with those in the community who fear full privatisation will mean a lower standard of services. No more will be sold until we are assured beyond doubt by an independent inquiry that standards will not fall. No-one on this side of the House would contemplate sale further than 49 per cent unless we have ironclad guarantees on standards.

I urge the people of regional Australia to consider the further benefits which will flow from the passage of these bills. The Prime Minister uses the term `social bonus' to describe benefits that will accrue. But I point out to honourable members that the social bonus is, in reality, an investment in infrastructure, our great regions and the people of those regions.

Direct benefits will be an increase in the Natural Heritage Trust by $250 million; rural transaction centres, $70 million over five years; extended access to untimed local calls, $150 million over three years; meeting the telecommunications needs of people in remote and isolated island communities or the Australian Antarctic Territory, $20 million over three years; Internet access for people in rural and regional areas, $36 million over three years; mobile phone coverage along highways, $25 million over three years; and, finally but not least, a television fund to enable improved television reception, extend coverage of SBS television and to support a new media unit to be established within the SBS, $120 million over five years.

In summary, as a member who comes from regional Australia—I have a regional electorate—this package of bills provides an enormous opportunity for this parliament to move towards full private ownership of Telstra and to enable the government to enter the next century without a debt problem while at the same time investing in our people and our regions. The bills also give the people of regional Australia—in fact, all Australians—ironclad guarantees on consumer service standards, customer service standards, transparency and many other safeguards. I therefore commend these bills to the House.

talk.start.para: —Before we give consideration to the sale of the next tranche of Telstra, I want to make some observations about what has happened with the first tranche and then I will turn to some of the specifics associated with this bill, the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 , some of the broader questions of the privatisation of Telstra and also the purported justification for this—the question of Australia's debt.

speech.para: The Auditor-General conducted an inquiry into the sale of the first tranche of Telstra and he had some very interesting findings. He found in an overall sense that there was a $65 million overrun on the budget for the sale—$210 million was the budget for the sale costs and the ultimate cost was $275 million. The Auditor-General found that the global coordinators, the people who organised and managed the sale on behalf of the government, were chosen before a fee arrangement was outlined and that a fee was negotiated with them after the conclusion of that effective tender process. In other words, we had, I suppose, a beauty contest—all the various bidders were there putting forward proposals as to how they would proceed with the sale and what fees they would charge. An outcome was negotiated with a consortium and then, after those people were designated as the successful tenderers who would conduct the sale, negotiations were entered into with them for the price, the fees, that they would be paid in order to do the sale. Hardly surprisingly, the Auditor-General concluded that this was a rather peculiar way to conduct a public sector privatisation; a very peculiar way to choose somebody to be the global coordinator of that privatisation.

But the story gets worse; the story gets even more peculiar. We see, for example, that the success benchmarks that were set by the Office of Asset Sales to determine what the success fees would be were actually set below those that in effect were recommended by the 1996 scoping study and below those that were recommended by the March 1997 Office of Asset Sales recommendations. The Auditor-General concluded that this cost the taxpayer somewhere between $5.4 million and $10.3 million. You might think that is small in the context of a privatisation that ultimately yielded in the vicinity of $14 billion, but nonetheless that is still $5 million to $10 million worth of taxpayers' money that this government threw away.

But the story does not end there and it gets even more peculiar. Almost $500,000 in success fees was paid to the global coordinators, most of them with respect to shares that they gave away. These people got paid money to give shares away. I would not mind getting a job like that. It is pretty easy money if you are giving shares away. But that is what happened. Four hundred and sixty-eight thousand dollars of the success fees related to bonus shares that were given away to Telstra staff members as part of the loyalty program. They got paid $468,000 to give shares away. Another $26,000 of the success fees related to shares that were not sold.

So they managed to cop a pretty hefty whack for shares that they gave away and an extra little bonus for shares that never went anywhere that the government still owns. A total of about $500,000 has been paid in success fees, which was clearly unnecessary and—to rub salt into the wound—was actually not obligatory under the contract between the Commonwealth and the global coordinators. According to the Office of Asset Sales, it was simply understood that they would have to pay this money. Five hundred thousand dollars of taxpayers' money later, you have got a situation where these people have been paid to give shares away or paid for not organising the sale of shares.

The international roadshow that was undertaken to promote the sale overseas was originally budgeted at $1 million and it ended up costing $3.1 million, $600,000 of which related to limousines, private plane hire and the like. Some of the money that was spent, it was ultimately concluded by the Auditor-General, did not relate to the sale of Telstra. The Auditor-General concluded that this expenditure was `not independently verified through appropriate supporting documentation and an effective audit trail was not maintained'.

And the story continues. Five million dollars worth of underwriting fees was paid with respect to shares for which no underwriting was actually required. There is a range of other minor losses: $700,000 lost because no foreign exchange hedging occurred with respect to certain payments to subcontractors which should have occurred. There were delays in processing applications. I have spoken to people who worked in the call centre and the like at the time and they said it was simply chaotic. These delays cost the taxpayer somewhere between $1.2 million and $2 million, according to the Auditor-General.

So the first sale—however much it has been touted as a great success for the government—organisationally and in terms of the interests of the taxpayer, was a total fiasco. But the critical issue in all this was that the first sale was massively underpriced. The Auditor-General found that, in spite of the fact that obviously you cannot get these things precisely right—obviously share markets are not easy to predict and hindsight is a wonderful thing—the first tranche sale was massively underpriced.

If you want a really good way of seeing this, if you want a really simple way of identifying this, all you have to do is look at the explanatory material for the proposed sale of the second tranche, which is 16.7 per cent, and see that it is estimated that that will yield somewhere between $10 billion and $15 billion. The first tranche was 33 per cent, double that, and what did it yield? Fourteen billion dollars. In other words, we are likely to get the same proceeds for the second tranche of 16½ per cent that we got for the first tranche of 33 per cent.

The Auditor-General found that the value of Telstra shares post-sale had increased 160 times the all-ordinaries index increase over that period. It is no wonder that we have seen a spate of articles in the quality media about how the Minister for Finance and Administration is the pin-up boy of the big end of town. He has been throwing money in their direction like a man with no arms. He is having a great time promoting his reputation and making people feel good about privatisation, but ultimately at the expense of the Australian taxpayer and the Australian government.

I turn to the question of the second tranche. It is interesting to see that the government has not learned from what has gone on in the sale of the first tranche of Telstra. We see that it is estimated in the explanatory material that roughly 1.5 per cent to two per cent of the proceeds of the sale of the second tranche, or ultimately the balance of Telstra, will be required for sale costs—commissions, fees and the like.

It does not take much complicated arithmetic to work out that that is going to amount to somewhere in the vicinity of $800 million to $1.1 billion. So, in other words, we have a billion dollar bonus for bankers in the second sale of Telstra. It is interesting to compare it with the social bonus that we heard talked about earlier tonight, which is estimated to be $671 million. So we have a social bonus, $670 million-odd, dwarfed by the bankers' bonus.

From a broader point of view, it is worth querying the logic, the basis, on which these sales are conducted and the fact that they are conducted on a percentage fee basis, which seems out of all proportion to the associated obligations, the risk, the management activities, that the intermediaries who are employed to do it actually undertake. When you are talking about a billion dollars to sell shares in a market that is already established, that is already mature, that is already traded, you really have to question the value for money that the taxpayer is getting out of this. Again, it does not matter if this is only a small percentage of the total. You are talking about $1 billion, some of which could ultimately be used to very good effect for other things.

It is abundantly clear that there will be a full sale. We have a fig leaf of an inquiry put there to satisfy some of the elements in the coalition's backbench and to pretend to the electorate at the previous election that the coalition perhaps was not going to sell all of Telstra. It is clear that there will be a full sale. The fact that makes that blindingly obvious is that in this legislation there is no requirement for that issue to come back to parliament. The minister simply decides whether or not there will be another 51 per cent sale, declares that the inquiry has found that it is quite all right to go ahead—maybe with one or two additional sops, a bit more money here, a little extra social bonus there—and it will go ahead.

This is another example—it is not the first—of a major privatisation being done by this government without any reference to parliament. We saw it with the Australian National sale, where the legislation that was put through the parliament effectively said, `The ministers are empowered to do whatever they like,' including being empowered to, by decree, repeal an existing act of parliament. Even worse, we saw it with the sale of the Australian National Line. Legislation was presented to the parliament. It went through this House and it went over to the Senate and it sat there. It is still sitting there, but ANL of course has been sold in the meantime.

The social bonus adds up, as I said, over a period of five years to $670 million—the odd rural transaction centre, untimed local calls here and there, some money for isolated communities, regional Internet access and the like, all of them good things. But the question that has to be asked about that is: what follows? It will be useful in the short term, it sounds good, and it is very politically effective if you have a few disaffected supporters, disaffected backbenchers, in regional Australia. But there is no overriding vision of the future of telecommunications in this country. There is nothing about content. Content is going to be the future, not only of this industry but ultimately a very big driver of the Australian economy. Yet there is nothing about generating content. Some of the good ideas on that issue that were in Creative Nation, the program initiated by the former Keating government, contrary to promises that were made by John Howard, are being unravelled.

There is a range of broader issues that all of us—not only government but the opposition as well—have to address in this debate, a range of very difficult issues. We have now got a hybrid, not courtesy of what we have created—nothing to do with us. Whether we like it or not, we have now got a hybrid. We have got a part publicly owned, part privately owned organisation which is involved in everything from the provision of the most basic telecommunications services, which are essential to ordinary civilised existence in our society, through to a fairly substantial range of entrepreneurial activities. It functions, for example, through Telstra Big Pond as an ISP, an Internet service provider. There are a range of other activities going on through Telstra that clearly are not essential telecommunications services, certainly not at this stage. In the more distant future they may well end up being so. None of us knows precisely how society will evolve.

We are going to have to confront the question not of who owns Telstra but of what should Telstra do. What activities, particularly if it remains part public owned, should it be involved in? Ownership is ultimately the best form of regulation. Part ownership, even if it is 67 per cent, more so if it is 51 per cent, clearly is a very limited weapon in pursuing your objectives through ownership. So we have an issue we have to think very carefully about—the future of telecommunications in this country, the future role that Telstra will play, particularly if, as the Labor Party believes it should, it continues to act as a publicly owned provider of a very diverse range of telecommunications services.

At first blush it is worth considering the question of structural separation. I think there are some fairly strong arguments as to why that is going to have to happen in some form, regardless of whether Telstra ends up being in part public ownership or fully private ownership. The great difficulty with that, which we will have to wrestle with, is precisely how do you separate it, given that the natural monopoly component of Telstra is changing all the time, the competition with respect to infrastructure and services is blurring the division between the two and technology is changing all the time? So defining things like `a basic telecommunications service' or `an essential service' is becoming increasingly difficult.

We will have issues from the other players in the market about the connection between some of Telstra's entrepreneurial activities and its dominance as the primary infrastructure provider, notwithstanding the ACCC regulatory framework. So these are all things that we are going to have to think about, things that will be very important issues in the future of telecommunications in this country. Yet what we are getting at the moment is essentially a fire sale that is driven by politics—driven by ideology, yes, but ultimately driven by politics—driven by the desire to have a nice little bundle of money to throw around from time to time at elections, to throw at some natural constituencies through natural heritage trusts and the like, fix up a few dams here and throw a few bits of money at various things there, not the right things to do by the environment but capable of being portrayed in that way, with no vision whatsoever for the future of communications, which ultimately is going to be the driver of Australia's economic prosperity. This industry more than any other will determine our future economic prosperity. This government has no serious vision about what it is going to do.

I would now like to turn to the question of debt. The primary reason that is portrayed for why we should be selling Telstra is that we have an allegedly vast amount of government debt and that if we sell Telstra we will be able to pay off a lot of it. The full sale would, on current market value, realise somewhere in the vicinity of $53 billion. Current net Commonwealth debt is about $83 billion.
Mr Hardgrave interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You will hear a bit more about that in a minute, if you shut up and listen. If the surplus is maintained and other asset sales continue as proposed, that debt will be significantly lower. But, of course, the dividend that Telstra provides will be lost. Particularly as Telstra is currently earning a fairly low rate of return on capital, given its market capitalisation, that is a very foolish decision on the part of this government. Around the markets at the moment, the suggestion is being made that Telstra really should have a rate of return of somewhere around $6 to $9 billion per annum, which to some degree ignores its recent monopoly and public sector background. Nonetheless, that pressure will continue to build.

speech.para: It is time that we had a bit of rational debate on public sector debt in this country. The reason why the conservatives are opposed to debt has nothing to do with fiscal responsibility, government accounting or anything like that; the reason they are opposed to debt is that they are opposed to government. They are opposed to government intervention, governments doing things and the collective provision of community services. They are opposed to redistribution. One way that these things are funded is through government debt. We hear that $95 billion worth of government debt was left to the incoming government and that from 1990 to 1996 this skyrocketed. They forget what happened before 1990, when it was substantially reduced. They use the period immediately prior to the recession as the benchmark and ignore the fact that substantial deficit budgets were run in the early 1990s, unlike the substantial surplus budgets run in the late 1980s, for obvious countercyclical economic reasons.

Let us look at some of the statistics on debt. In 1990, the Commonwealth public debt was down to 4.3 per cent of GDP. As a result of the recession, it went up to 19.5 per cent of GDP, or about $95 billion. But, in the same period, state and local government debt and public sector trading enterprise debt substantially reduced from about 10 per cent of GDP to 4.8 per cent in the case of state and local government debt and, in the case of public sector trading enterprises, from 15.2 per cent to 8.2 per cent of GDP. So the overall total net government debt over that period—that is, across Australia in all levels of government, including government trading enterprises—only increased from 27 per cent of GDP to 35.7 per cent of GDP in 1995-96.

The percentage of the Commonwealth budget spent on servicing Commonwealth debt actually went down to 5.7 per cent of the total budget in 1992-93. It crept up again to 7.6 per cent, which is the level it was at a couple of years prior to 1992-93, in 1995-96. These figures are significantly affected by external factors such as the value of the Australian dollar. It depends on which currency the debt is denominated in and the like. It also depends on interest rates. But the overall picture is nothing like the phoney debt crisis that the conservatives have whipped up as an excuse to privatise and to cut government spending.

Look at the debt levels across the OECD in 1995 before we left office. Look, for example, at interest payments on government debt as a proportion of the gross domestic product. For Australia, it was 2.3 per cent; UK, three per cent; US, 2.1 per cent; Germany, 3.2 per cent; France, 3.5 per cent; Canada, 5.6 per cent; Italy, 10.1 per cent; the Netherlands, 4.6 per cent; and Sweden, 2.8 per cent—and so it goes on. In other words, when we left office, interest payments on government debt were only fractionally higher as a proportion of GDP than they were in the United States.

Debt is a useful tool provided that it is used in moderation. It is also important because it is about having future generations pay for infrastructure that is provided today rather having it paid all by current generations. That is provided you have the capacity to service the debt and it does not take a huge percentage of your budget. It needs to be under control in the same way that if you mortgage a house you need to be able to meet the repayments. It is reasonable.

We did not have a debt crisis. We had a cyclical situation which was going to be brought under control regardless of who was returned to government. The economy was continuing to improve because of the measures taken by the former government. So the suggestion that debt is the reason why Telstra has to be sold is completely baseless. We do not want substantial debt in Australia. We have not had substantial debt in Australia. We have been a relatively low government debt country compared with the rest of the OECD and the developed world, and that continues to be the case. The suggestion, which is being put forward by the current government, that we have had this outrageous debt crisis is simply not true. It is not borne out by the figures. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The honourable member for Melbourne, in his capacity as the Labor spokesman for finance, has shown a case for the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 and a case against the former government. In his own way, he has given us a codified understanding that the sale of Telstra is a good thing and that the previous government's handling of the economy was a sad thing. Having said all that, I am very concerned that if the particular group opposite should ever happen to find its way back on this side of the chamber and we see that gentleman as finance minister, he will make Kim Beazley look like an absolute genius.

speech.para: I am in favour of the bill before us today. I am in favour of the full sale of Telstra for one very simple reason: it will produce cheaper phone calls for the people in my electorate of Moreton. There is also a bunch of other benefits, which I will go into in a moment. As the member for Melbourne rightly said, this industry is the one where our future prosperity as a nation is hinged. The communications and information technology industry is also one where jobs will be created and are created. So it is important, as this government is showing, to set free the biggest player in the market from the shackles of government ownership. This will let it do what all the other companies involved in the provision of communications in this country are doing. So it is very clearly a bill for the future.

Ownership is not important. What is important is to treat all 24 providers of telecommunications in this country in exactly the same way. There has been a lot of talk in the months leading up to this debate about rural and regional Australia. However, it is certainly not the whole story of telecommunications in this country. It is worth noting early in my contribution that the universal service obligation is officially worth $250 million but that Telstra claims it could be worth $1.8 billion. That is money that is redirected from the overall telecommunications industry to directly help rural and regional Australia maintain its contact with the world.

The system in the bush may need further improvement. Some say, `Don't do anything about selling Telstra until matters are fixed up in the bush.' But I say that the best prospects for rural and regional Australia come from the sale of Telstra and the competition which will be enhanced by this process. Rural and regional Australia will find, just as will metropolitan Australia, that more providers offering more services and cheaper prices—and this is not just ideology, it is history—will be the great benefits. For rural and regional Australia the difference, of course, is the timetable: services and access to services in the city will be available, but in the bush it will take a little longer.

But this government's demand of all service providers—and, in the main, that is Telstra—is to contribute to the concept of universal service for all Australians. This shows this particular government's commitment to communications throughout Australia, even throughout a time when the government no longer owns Telstra. This really does prove the point of this legislation. Ownership is one thing, but the rules and regulations governing overall telecommunications in this country clearly are another. Anyone who tells you otherwise is not thinking of today but trying to hold us back as an international communications and information economy provider.

The bill is part of the government's plan for building a stronger Australia. It maintains most of the provisions of the Telstra (Transition to Full Public Ownership) Bill 1998, which was introduced in the 38th Parliament. However, the government has taken on board a number of well-intentioned concerns and, through listening to people, it has produced some significant variations.

For instance, Telstra must meet prescribed criteria for service performance for a designated period of at least six months before the Commonwealth can relinquish majority ownership. The evaluation of Telstra's performance in metropolitan, rural and remote areas will be undertaken by an independent inquiry. The inquiry must issue a certificate confirming that Telstra has, in fact, met those prescribed service standards and must provide it to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston.

The Telstra Corporation Act is amended by this bill to require Telstra to ensure that at least two of its directors have knowledge of, or experience in, the communications needs of rural areas of Australia. The ministerial power to direct Telstra in section 9 of the Telstra Corporation Act will be retained until the Commonwealth relinquishes its majority interest. This direction power is somewhat inappropriate for a privately owned company. But, following the sale of the majority interest, Telstra will be subject to the sorts of controls and directions that all other telecommunications providers are subject to—appropriate regulatory powers, ministerial direction powers and other legislative powers which protect consumers and competitors. This will complete the proper separation of regulation from ownership of the company.

This bill also will ensure that the existing 35 per cent total, and five per cent individual, foreign ownership limits, which were applied in the first tranche of the sale of Telstra, will continue to apply to the proportion of non-Commonwealth shares following the sale of each tranche. That is, the limits will continue to apply, no matter how subsequent share sales are structured. The requirement for Telstra's headquarters, chairman and majority of directors to be Australian will be retained, irrespective of the ownership of Telstra.

This bill also makes amendments to the ACCC and industry requirements to improve two safeguards for consumers. Consistent with the government's election commitments—this is a government which tells the electors of its intentions before an election, and fulfils them—this bill contains new provisions requiring the ACCC to provide regular, impartial, public reports on pricing, market share and other competition related data across a range of specified areas.

A number of arguments are put. In fact, one that is often put is that Telstra pays a dividend and that we should not sell off a productive asset. The dividend in 1997-98 was $1.2 billion, and that certainly is a lot of money. But the sale of Telstra will also release a lot of money to government to repay debt—debt which the Australian Labor Party clocked up during its 13 years in office.

Public debt is shared by every person in this country: it is worth about $10,000 per man, woman and child. It is debt which in 1997-98 cost this nation almost $8.3 billion in interest alone. That is $8.3 billion in debt-interest servicing costs in 1997-98, the same year that Telstra achieved a $1.2 billion dividend. It is not hard to tell which side of the ledger we have to look at. Telstra would need to improve its dividend something like five- or six-fold to meet the bill of interest on debt—a debt principal which will be substantially paid off as a result of this government's intentions.

Foreign debt weighs us down and consigns our children to repay what we have spent. Public debt interest of $8.3 billion is over three-quarters of the defence budget and about 1½ times the amount of money that we put aside for veterans in this country. It is obvious to me that repaying debt is a great advantage for today as well as for tomorrow.

Then there are those who say that governments should not sell assets. Labor gave asset sales a very bad name. It sold off assets like Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank and more, even after having said before an election that they would not. Yet those particular asset sales did nothing for the benefit of our nation. When Labor sold assets, Labor put that money into today's expenditure; it was a bit like selling the family car to pay for the weekly groceries. But the Howard government has instead used asset sales to retire debt; we have, if you like, sold the family car to repay the home loan.

It is interesting to reflect on the contribution by the member for Melbourne that maybe there was too much money spent by this government to process the sale of the first third of Telstra; that, in fact, the percentage of proceeds caught up in the costs associated with the sale was about 1.8 per cent of the total proceeds of $14.3 billion.

The Australian Labor Party, when they were in government in 1995, sold Qantas and spent 2.8 per cent—not 1.8 per cent but 2.8 per cent—of the proceeds on the costs associated with that sale. When they sold CSL in 1994 and realised $299 million, they spent 3.1 per cent of that amount on the costs of effecting that sale. Not only could they not use the actual amount of money that was generated from the sale of those assets productively and properly for the benefit of this country, like in the repayment of debt, Labor also spent more money to make the sale happen. So everything that the member for Melbourne has spoken of in his contribution tonight, multiply it for Labor, Madam Deputy Speaker.

We delivered on what we said we would do with the first third of Telstra sold. That is, we turned the money into worthwhile projects for today and tomorrow. We are going to do it again with this next stage sale process. In addition, we will again allocate direct benefits paid for, not borrowed against, by the sale of the next part of Telstra. We will not do what Labor did: we will not go into debt. We are going to repay more of Labor's debt. When the proceeds from this next sale reach $671 million—which is the total cost of the social bonus elements—the money will be allocated automatically.

For instance, the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Act 1997 is amended by this bill to increase the trust's reserve fund by $250 million. This will build further the funding base for what is already the largest environment fund in Australia's history. This money is used in my own electorate to regenerate Oxley Creek and Norman Creek—both urban waterways that are under pressure. But the Australian Labor Party did nothing about them during their 13 years in office. This money has also helped to finance a pilot sewage treatment project at the Rocklea Treatment Works. Secondary treated sewage will flow through this particular melaleuca forest. Nature will have its way, and cleaner water will therefore flow into the Brisbane River. This particular project has begun with funding under the `Clean Seas and Coastal Waterways' segment of the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, which Senator Robert Hill announced a few months ago in my electorate.

I want to see money from the proceeds of the sale of Telstra go to other worthwhile projects in my electorate—for example, other urban waterways like Mimosa Creek, Bulimba Creek, Rocky Water Holes Creek and Stable Swamp Creek. They all flow from or have tributaries which flow from Toohey Forest, which is at the heart of my electorate of Moreton. The Moreton electorate will certainly enjoy great benefits from the regeneration of these waterways. Each flow into the Brisbane River and out into Moreton Bay.

While a number of good, committed local people have worked hard to raise with me and others the need for additional funds, proceeds from the sale of the first third of Telstra did not go far enough to meet the full extent of the need in my electorate. But there is already evidence of real and tangible benefit coming from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, set up as a result of the sale of the first third of Telstra. The potential projects will each be enhanced by the value adding volunteers which will come into the equation. Relatively small amounts of money will go a long way in my electorate and will produce some real results.

Funds will also go to other major projects in other parts of Australia. There are major environmental projects and other projects which will enhance and expand our telecommunications possibilities, including $25 million which will provide 100 per cent continuous mobile phone coverage on key major national highways in this country. This is not a fire sale just to refinance Australia's economic position or to repay Labor's debt. It will provide a lot of future benefits, such as repairing our economy. It will also set up a regime which will build a strong, competitive telecommunications industry for our nation—a regime where all competitors will be treated the same.

As I said before, there are 24 participants in the marketplace now offering telecommunications services. Each one is having its share of difficulty doing exactly what it wants to do. At the moment Telstra is the 800-pound gorilla in the marketplace, and the other 23 players feel Telstra is protected by government ownership. However, the biggest issue is not ownership. It is access to the network so that players and aspirants can gain access to the system to provide the completion of the business that they are offering people. As a result of Telstra's quite deliberate market domination tactics, Australians are simply not getting the cost savings that they deserve. As a result of this bill, the way that it sets Telstra free and puts everybody on the same basic set of rules, we can start to see some change.

It is important that Telstra's privatisation does not further entrench Telstra's market domination, especially in those services that it has and continues to have a virtual monopoly in. In particular, I am speaking about the local call loop—the network infrastructure between local exchange and the 98 per cent of homes and businesses which have a telephone.

Privatisation and completing the sale of Telstra will lead to overall public benefit. It is more than just the provision of telephone services. At the heart of the commonsense behind the government's aspirations is the savings to our nation in the provision of services which have become and will continue to become a key part of daily lives. To provide those services at a cheaper cost is good news for all Australians.

Consumer protection measures are contained in this bill, as is a restatement of those universal service obligations which we on this side demand must continue. But there is no longer going to be one rule for Telstra and one rule for everyone else. Telstra can no longer enjoy special privileges from public ownership or, for that matter, even some special obligations.

To sum up, this bill is part of a legislative package which will clearly separate regulation of the telecommunications industry from the ownership question of Telstra. Put simply, it does not matter who owns the phone company, as long as the rules are well understood and well stated to all people involved in the industry. This is a clear sign to the entire telecommunications industry at its critical growth stage and to the world that the government's eye is on today and tomorrow in every possible way.

No-one is really criticising Telstra, because it has played a significant role—a great role—in Australia's development. In its evolving form and logic, Telstra has been at the heart of growth and the opening up of vast areas of Australia. It has been at the heart of infrastructure provision for almost a century. But we are no longer waiting for telegrams in order to find out what is happening to those who are dear to us. We no longer visit our well-off next-door neighbours' homes hoping that we might be able to borrow the phone if we put down a sixpence to cover the cost of the call. We no longer look at Star Trek and think that personal communicators are some futuristic ideal that we may never ever realise.

The world has changed; it has evolved. We on this side understand that, and we are not going to hold on to the old arrangements or the old ownerships. Our preselections are not threatened by the Socialist Left unions, the Telstra unions. We are looking at the future benefits for all Australians, be they lower income people, pensioners or the older people in my electorate who want to have cheaper phone calls and the certainty of a range of prospects as far as service provision is concerned, or be they big or middle sized companies or small businesses which are paying too much on a daily, weekly or monthly basis for their telecommunications needs.

The world has moved on. Everybody on this side knows that, but those opposite have not quite cottoned on. While we are prepared today to move on and face the challenges of tomorrow with this sort of legislation and to pay off yesterday's debt that those opposite clocked up over 13 years in government, what are we getting from those opposite? Plenty of argument, rhetoric, resistance and old-fashioned nexus to the union movement—all of the things that will hold Australia back.

We are going into the 21st century. Those opposite must realise that the year 2000 is only about 14 months away, so we had better get on with the job now and not hold on to the past. The 20th century is just about over. While Telstra has changed and evolved and we have changed and evolved, and we understand that this is the next step, those opposite are resisting the change for ideological reasons; and I have to say that, for a lot of reasons, that is quite pathetic. There are so many benefits and pluses to be gained as a result of passing this bill. I ask those opposite to reconsider their position for the good of all Australians.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be able to make a contribution to the debate on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 this evening, and I do so not only as a member of this parliament but also as a shareholder in Telstra. When the original debate around the privatisation of Telstra was under way, I vociferously opposed the part privatisation then, as I will oppose this bill today.

speech.para: Unfortunately, the member for Moreton and, I think, a majority of people on the government benches have not cottoned on to what this argument is really about. I speak with a bit of knowledge about what it is to live in a remote region in Australia and how important telecommunications infrastructure is for the people who live in those communities.

I will give you a bit of personal history. I started working in the north-west of South Australia in a little Aboriginal community called Pipalyatjara in 1978. I worked there on and off for about three years, and I spent a lot of time there. The only means of communicating with the outside world from that small community—which is basically at the junction of the Northern Territory, Western Australia and South Australia—was through the Royal Flying Doctor Service schedule on the radio. That meant that conversations about business or private matters were there for everyone who tuned into the Flying Doctor schedule to hear. Privacy was not an issue, because there wasn't any; but, importantly, that schedule was available a couple of times a day. There were no fax machines and no access to computer technology or the Internet. When I was working out of Alice Springs, if someone wanted to deliver a message, it invariably meant a 10-hour drive in the hope that they might see someone to have a meeting, and often, as is the case in these remote communities, the person they wanted to speak to was not there.

In 1985, the Labor government, through Telstra, initiated quite a magnificent program for rural and remote areas. The purpose of this rural and remote area program was to provide a basic telephone service to people in the bush through the USO—the universal service obligation. Telstra used a system of microwave bearers—the digital radio concen trator system, or DRCS—and gradually, over a five- or six-year period, the world was opened up to people who lived in regional and remote Australia.

I know this to be a fact. Prior to the introduction of this technology, basic though it is, people had no access to telephonic services or fax. All of a sudden, a modern office could be born, and people could actually communicate with one another privately. People who lived on pastoral properties, in Aboriginal communities or in mining camps could talk to their spouses a long way away, check up on the family health and access information from universities and other learning institutions.

I argued at the time, and I maintain that this argument holds true today, that the positive externalities of providing that infrastructure far outweigh the capital cost of its provision. The savings that were made through efficiency in servicing those communities and the social and economic outcomes that were delivered by that infrastructure are very hard to measure, but if they were measurable—and they are—they would demonstrate very clearly that the investment in that infrastructure, expensive though it was, paid handsome dividends.

We have moved on from 1990 when that infrastructure rollout was all but completed. Remember that this was the period when Aussat was not travelling too well and satellite communications were very expensive. Telstra had difficulty getting customers and the technology was not the best. It basically put all its eggs in one basket by using the DRCS system—a terrestrial system.

Unfortunately for Telstra, and unfortunately for the people who live in remote Australia, they have done very little to it since. That, I think, is a real issue here. Whilst people on the other side of this place can argue about the efficiencies that might be gained in the marketplace in Sydney or Melbourne, or up the fringe of the coast, and the cost reductions that can be brought about as a result of competition—and I am an advocate of competition—that cannot be said for the bush.

These other organisations are not breaking their necks to deliver services to really remote regions. Let me tell you: they are not. You do not see alternative carriers marching around remote communities offering their wares. There are a number reasons for that, and I will come to those in a moment. The bottom line is that, whilst we have a universal service obligation, which is legislated, and whilst we have a carrier that is majority public owned—to my way of thinking it should have been retained in total public ownership but, nevertheless, it is still majority public owned—we have an influence over that company which we would not have if we were to pursue the objectives of the government, and that means a great deal.

I will come in a moment to the debate which has emerged within Telstra and within the telecommunications industry about the universal service obligations and Telstra's obligation as a company that is majority public owned. The statements which were made by the chairman of that company were widely reported in the business press. I have in front of me an extract from the weekend Australian Financial Review of November 7 and 8 in which Telstra Corp Ltd's chairman, David Hoare, basically lambasted the government and the Australian taxpayers, who are the majority shareholders of Telstra, when he said that the company ought to be privatised. The extract states:

Mr Hoare also called for the government to sell its remaining two-thirds of the company after the Australian Shareholders' Association queried how the board intended to deal with an apparent conflict of interest relating to Telstra's obligation to the government to provide a national service. "You have highlighted the conflict of interest, where the Government remains the majority shareholder and carries the responsibility for competition policy—that's a very compelling argument for the total privatisation of Telstra."

Well, is it? What is that code for? That is code for saying that the commercial interests of the shareholders are more important than the social and political interests of the government. In effect, what they are saying is that they can cut themselves loose from the universal service obligations under this process—that is, at least in terms of the commitment that they currently make. They are thereby saying to those people who live in rural and remote areas in Australia that, although there has been a diminishing service since we went through the part-privatisation, they will get an ever increasing diminishing service as a result of full privatisation. The facts are very clear.

I notice the adviser nodding his head, and well he might, because it is very clear that the standard of service for people who live in rural and remote Australia has declined substantially since 1996. Let me quote some figures which have come from the Australian Communications Authority telecommunications performance bulletin. These figures reflect a position where services connected over five different areas have decreased in every one of those areas since the December quarter of 1996.

For the December 1996 quarter, the figure for services connected on or before the ACD was 82 per cent. For information, this is the percentage of new services connected on or before the agreed communications date, ACD. This is a date agreed between the customer and Telstra which is acceptable to the customer and realistic in terms of available work force. The figure in December 1996 was 82 per cent and for the June quarter of 1998 the figure was 73 per cent. For faults cleared within one working day, the figures were 74 per cent for December 1996 and 62 per cent for June 1998. For faults cleared within two working days, the figures were 90 per cent in June 1996 and 81 per cent in the June quarter of 1998. For pay phone faults cleared within one working day the figures were 67 per cent in 1996 and 48 per cent in 1998. For pay phone faults cleared within two working days the figures were 84 per cent in 1996 and 68 per cent in June 1998.

There has been a massive deterioration in the level of services which have been going to the bush. The only people who have twigged on it on the government side of the House are those in the National Party. They did it before the election and no doubt they will give the government a bit of ginger before this debate is over. It is very clear that the people who will wear the impact of this absurd policy of the government are the people in the bush—the people I care about.

Let me go a little further. In the Northern Territory—these figures come from the Performance Monitoring Bulletin, June 1998 quarter—the figures for performance in rural areas are even worse. For rural areas in the Northern Territory, the figure for fault clearances within two working days was 58 per cent, whereas the national average in March of 1998 was 82 per cent. This is effectively handicapping people who need communications systems. Who is responsible? Well one might ask.

We have got the universal service obligation but what we have not got is a Telstra management committed to providing these services to people in the bush. What we have got is a debate about the level of this universal service obligation. I note with some interest this debate about what the level of universal service obligation should be. You will recall, Madam Deputy Speaker, that the government has, I think, put a figure of some $253 million on the cost of the universal service obligation. The Australian Financial Review of Wednesday 21 October makes the comment that there is a discussion in the telecommunications industry as to what the true value of this universal service obligation could be, because of course the higher the figure the greater cost burden there is on Telstra's competitors.

The minority shareholders, as has been pointed out by the chairman of Telstra, do not buy competition; they want dividends. That is what they are after—the dividends from their investment, not the policy outcomes that a government should want to achieve by providing this sort of infrastructure in remote and rural Australia.

It is interesting that when Bellcorp, a US telecommunications industry consultant, was appointed to devise a model based on what it would cost to deliver telephone services if the entire Telstra rural network was replaced today as required by law, when they inserted Telstra data into the Bellcorp model, it was revealed that roughly 493,000 rural Australian customers were unprofitable and being subsidised.
